editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Generous Enemies OR THE Ridiculous Lovers.
As it is Acted at the THEATRE ROYAL by His MAIESTIES Servants.
LONDON, Printed by H. Lloyd for James Magnus in Ruſſel-ſtreet, near the Piazza. 1672.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE.
div.l: I Cannot chooſe but laugh, when I look back and ſee
The ſtrange Viciſſitudes of Poetrie.
Your Aged Fathers came to Plays for Wit,
And ſat Knee-deep in Nut-ſhells in the Pit.
Courſe Hangings then in ſtead of Scenes were worn,
And Kidderminſter did the Stage Adorn.
But you, their wiſer Off-ſpring, do advance
To Plot of Gigg; and to Dramatique Dance:
But when the Reign of Gigg and Dance is paſt,
Whither the Devil will you go at laſt
What yet unheard-of Way can Poets try,
To pleaſe theſe Modern Criticks of the eye▪
There's one Way left, as when ill Husbands Range,
The come at laſt to their own Wives for change;
So you your Surfet of old Wit now paſt,
May come to taſte it with new Guſt at laſt.
And having through all Uſurpations run,
May fix upon the King, where you begun.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.
div.l: ALL their Beginning know, but none their End,
And with that Fate we on your Votes depend.
Though there I ſee—Propitious Angels ſit,
Still there's a Neſt of Devils in the Pit,
By whom our Plays, like Children, juſt alive,
Pinch'd by the Fairies, never after thrive:
'Tis but your Half-crown, Sirs: that won't undo;
Beſides, let others loſe't as well as you▪
Birds caught in Lime, or fool'd into a Gyn,
By chirping on ſtill draw Companions in:
Ginneys depart at Shutland for a Meal
Of ill Pottage, and rotten Roaſted Teal.
From thence you came inflam'd into the Pit,
And nothing pleaſes your Burgundy Wit;
Cenſure is grown, not judgment now, but faſhion,
And your ill Nature ſpoils your Recreation.
So doth an Entertainer marr his Feaſt,
With one o're-critical and peeviſh Gueſt.
As Woman let me with the Men prevail,
And with the Ladies as I look like Male.
'Tis worth your Money that ſuch Legs appear;
Theſe are not to be ſeen ſo cheap elſewhere:
In ſhort commend this Play, or by this light,
We will not ſup with one of you to night.

row.cell: A young Gentleman in love with Jaccinta, but belov'd by Alleria.
Semena in diſguiſe, Siſter to Flaminio.

div.head: THE Generous Enemies OR THE Ridiculous Lovers.
ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Signior Robatzy with four or five Servants running confuſedly with Buckets.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: FIre, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: See, ſee, ſee. Run, run, run. Down
With that Chimney there.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: More help, more help there.

sp.speaker: 3. Ser.
sp.l: Quick, quick, O Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: More water in that corner.

sp.speaker: 4. Ser.
sp.l: More Buckets.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Some of you ring out the bell.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Fear not, we ſhall ſoon overcome it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Which way is the wind?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Without danger, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Good Sir, withdraw your ſelf from this drudgery.
Here's hands enough, and we ſhall ſoon Maſter it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Let's to the other ſide, and ſee what danger's there.
sp.stage: The Scene changes to the Garden: then Enter Alvaro with Aleria in his Armes, ſhe in a Swoon.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thanks to the ſacred Guardian of the Saints,
For this moſt timely Refuge I have preſerv'd
Her from the Flames: has made a thouſand in
My ſoul; my fires find eternal nouriſhment,
And burn without conſuming; all others ceaſe
When the Materials fail that feed their fury;
But yet my ſoul yields to a ſad deſpair;
She appears to me, like fallen fruit, diſrob'd
Of all its luſtre, her charmes have loſt
Their graces, and death ſeems to triumph in
The Seats of Beauty, yet—
Sure it cannot be, her habit is not in the leaſt
Defac'd, the fright has only put her in a
Swoon, I will go ſeek her Servants, who may
Give her help.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: All corners of the houſe I've ſearch'd, yet cannot
Gain diſcovery where ſhe is, my fears foretel
My griefs, ſhe is devour'd in that impartial
Element; Juſt Heaven, is it poſſible you ſhould
Submit ſo fair a creature, to ſo foul
A deſtiny? O my ſoul, do I not ſee the
Figure of her there—
My faith deludes my hopes, it is not ſhe;
'Tis but her ſhadow, how can that lamp ſtill
Live, when life (the Oyl that fed it) is
Dry'd up: the mercileſs enemy hath made
A prey upon more worth then the Sun
(In its Meridian glory) ever fill'd his eye with▪
Ten thouſand curſes on thoſe envious flakes,
Proud only with the ruine of all that makes
Men happy: Alleria—She is out of hearing,
What a prodigious miſchief fills this houre.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How have I ſlept like cork upon the water
And had no feeling of the ſtorm that toſs'd me,
Where am I, who was it call'd?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Ev'n he, Madam, to whom your Misfortune
Is a death.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: How came I here, or you?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I was aſſiduous only in your ſafety, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: It is to you then whom I am thus indebted;
Was it your vigilance preſerv'd me? ah Caſſidore,
This Image of your love tranſcends all Preſidents,
It is a favour overwhelms my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: O beneficial errour.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Who but a man truly poſſeſt with love,
Could have undertaken ſo perillous a hazard;
Since I am ſo nobly oblig'd, I will ever own
It with the higheſt admiration.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Since ſhe is thus happily deceiv'd, I'le take
The advantage of it, an Amourers Lie hath
No great horrour in it.
Your generous Acknowledgment are too obliging
Madam? and puts a Die of baſhfulneſs upon
Your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: If ſuch favour, Sir, ſhould paſs forgotten, Honour
Would grow idle, and thankful Nature be beguil'd
Of her Employment.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: He that ſerves you does but his duty at
The beſt.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: You wrong your Generoſity to ſay ſo, ſuch
An act as this could never be the effect
Of common paſſion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O what a bleſſing is it, Madam, that you are
Safe preſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: See'ſt thou that man, that good man, all
Other men to him ſhould kneel and wonder,
I impute my ſafety, only to his care, for he
No ſooner ſaw the danger I was in, but with
A Paſſion, vehement as his griefs, ran through
The flames into my Chamber, where he found
Me overwhelmed with horrour, and thence in
Safety brought me to this place; was
It not ſo Caſſidore?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am aſtoniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: And yet ſo much Modeſty accompanies his
Worth, the praiſes due to this Action are,
As painful to his ear, as they are pleaſant.
To my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: To a man poſſeſt with love, always to ſhew it.
Are of pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Good Sir, let me prevail with you, to adde unto
Mine, my fathers preſervation, who, I fear,
May be indanger'd by this accident.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Madam, I flie with joy to all commands of yours.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your father, Madam, and all the houſhold are in
Safety, the flames are all extinguiſh'd, and
Without much prejudice, the fright was greater
Then the damage, Madam: it hapned well, we had
The Morning to our aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: She lives, ſhe lives, the angry Heavens at
Length have heard my prayers.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Yes, I do live, Alvarez, but do you know by
Whoſe means it is I am ſo happy:

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: It is from me, Madam, (only) you muſt learn the
Knowledge of your deliverance.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: How! your news ſurprizes me.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: It may well, Madam, when you have heard it,
For no ſooner was the horrid cry of fire, moſt
Diſmally proclaim'd through the ſtreets, but
With a winged diligence from my bed I roſe,
And haſtned to your refuge: I ran through the
Invading flames: that (like a Conquerour) had
Sack'd your houſe, and thrown diſorder round
About the place.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: She having found me ſleeping in my bed,
And Ruine in all her terrours round me:
You through theſe many dangers,
That you ſpeak of (with an unequal care)
Conveigh'd me to this place.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nothing mor • true, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Nothing more falſe;
By Innocence, I ſwear, I do not know thy Equall▪

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, Madam it was he ſent me hither
To your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Go, go, your confidence diſturbs me.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Is this the Gratitude due to my fidelity?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Away treacherous man.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: By all the Oaths made in fear of Heaven, all that
I have told you is a truth.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Ah direful perjury.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Have I watch'd all moments to expreſs reſpect,
And can it win no better eſtimation!

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Go thou Impoſtor, bluſh at thy deceit,
Thou ſinn'ſt againſt thy knowledge, and ſeek'ſt
A Recompence for what thou never did'ſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Ah Madam, where have you learn't the example
Of ſuch cruelty.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: All your diſſemblings ſhall never
Bribe me to a better thought, then what
My opinion doth already harbour.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: All my hopes mow'd down in their flower.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: O happy moment, this deſcenſion is above my hopes:

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: His't, his't, a word with you, Julia?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I dare not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nay prithee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How fain you would have me now betray my Myſtriſs

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Betray her, by my life I would not have thee
Wrong thy truſt ſo much, only tell me (if thou
Canſt) who it is uſurps the reward due to my ſervice▪

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I dare not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I prithee tell me, ſ • e here's a Jewel for thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What, ſell my Ladies ſecrets▪ may I
Die a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Come, come, be not a fool; this peeviſh principle
Of honeſty, has ruin'd more of thy quality then any
Misfortune whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How will my conſcience anſwer it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Hang Conſcience, 'tis the Rogues Conſumption;
What do you doubt my diſcretion, come
I'le warrant thee: the diſcovery ſhall never
Do thee wrong, here take it and wear it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Well, Signior, if I ſhould, 'tis but to pleaſe you:
I hope it is not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Counterfeit, doſt think me of ſo baſe a ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, pray Sir, pardon my innocence, if I did ſuſpect it.
His Name is Caſſidore, a Gentleman that lives
At the corner of the ſtreet, juſt againſt us:

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I know him well, he is a Servant to my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Well, well, Sir, let him be whoſe Servant he will,
It is as I tell you, Signior, and ſo farewel.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: My happineſs, like a weak vapour, is diſpers'd▪
As ſoon as riſen, could any ſoul but mine,
With which ſhe plays the Tyrant (after ſuch
Diſdains) flame with the ſame Ardour, I
Ought to ſigh: for thoſe ill-employ'd cares I once
Had to pleaſe her, but ſo much does my
Patience triumph over my affliction, that
In defiance of her rigour, I muſt ſtill
Worſhip her.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: 'Twas ever the effect of Fate, to blaſt the
Faireſt hopes: you are Poſſeſſor of a ſoul, too
Great, to bow to the reproaches of her pride.
There are other Beauties far ſurpaſſing hers,
Would count it happineſs, to ſhare but in
A ſigh of yours.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Swarmes of perplexing cares bury my
Brain: Never did Martyr ſuffer greater torment.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Yes, I dare tell you, Sir, of one deſerves compaſſion
More then you.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: 'Tis impoſſible my ſufferings ſhould have an equal.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: I am ſure you would confeſs it truth, might
I but take the boldneſs to relate it.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Prithee do, the relation of anothers ſorrows,
Sometimes helps to extenuate our own.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Now Love aſſiſt my trembling heart, I find a
Care riſe up before me, how I ſhould diſguiſe
My ſtory—
There was a young Lady, Sir, that lov'd me tenderly,
Who ſcarce had numbred 15 years, ere ſhe
Was ſought in Marriage, but he that was deſign'd
To have her, not being poſſeſt with equal flames,
Gave liberty to his heart to love another,
Which ſhe too well knew; yet ſuffer'd
In obedience to her Parents will; and yet a
Greater grief ſhe underwent, for that
Inſnarer of her faith, no ſooner drew
Her ſoul within the compaſs of an Oath, never
To marry any but himſelf, but then forſook her.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O barbarous infidelity.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Notwithſtanding this, her afflicted heart ſtill
Follow'd him, and in contempt of danger, and
The inconveniences that wait upon diſguiſes;
She (in a Maſculine habit) purſued and over▪
Took him. And ſuch was the ſtrangeneſs
Of her fate; She gain'd occaſion by the in‐
Terceſſion of thoſe, whom her calamity had
Made her friends to attend upon him.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Cruel injuſtice of our Stars,

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: And underwent it as a pleaſing bondage.
Performing all her ſervices with joy; he not
Knowing her, and ſhe is willing ſtill to be conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: That Love ſhould teach us ways to wrong our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: A melting pity creeps into his heart: Heaven
Make this minute happy to my wiſhes—
Now, Sir, tell me, is ſhe not worthy of compaſſion?
Sir, you do not anſwer me:—

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Civil Alleria.—

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Good gods, ſhe is ſtill in his mind—
Sir, you do not anſwer me to what I told you.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: What haſt thou ſpoken of?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: An unfortunate Maid, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: My ſoul was ſo oppreſs'd, I had no regard to
What thou ſaid'ſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: And yet you ſeem'd to caſt your pity on her.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thou art miſtaken, Boy, my thoughts were
All employ'd upon my own Misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Shall the loſs then of an imperious Myſtriſs
Be ſo repin'd; if you muſt needs think of her,
Think of her defects; call into your mind her
Pride, and view her cruelty with impartial eyes:
Behold her as I do, and then you needs muſt
Say, ſhe is deform'd, for nothing can be
Beautiful that is unjuſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Not beautiful; She has a face Envie it ſelf
Cannot but call fair; and all report of her
That is not ſuch, muſt give it ſelf the Lie:
But hold, who are thoſe?

div.stage: [Flam. gazeth on him, then runs to him, and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: I know 'em not Sir.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: By my life, Alvarez,
O never came joy to mankind welcomer.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Flaminio, O my beſt friend, I cannot
Make my joy rich enough with all the wealth of words.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: The ill ſtore lies on my ſide.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: —Heavens, my brother; how came he here?
I hope my diſguiſe will ſtill preſerve me undiſcover'd,
Beſides, I have not ſeen him many years.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: There's not a wiſh of kindneſs in thy breaſt,
But ſhall be multiply'd in mine; but what
Unuſual cauſe has brought thee into Spain.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: My Mother (by a Letter ſent to me from Rome)
Commanded my Arrival here at Sivil, with all
The haſte that I could make, aſſuring me that
About this time I might expect her here.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: But to what intent?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I am acquainted with nothing of her purpoſe,
Only receiv'd Commands from her to deliver
This Letter to Don Alonzo Robatzii, an
Eminent Inhabitant in this City, and one
That had a principal correſpondence with my
Father in his life-time.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I know him well, he is a near Neighbour
Of mine.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, I forgot to ask you
Of the welfare of your Siſter.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: When I left Florence, ſhe was inclin'd to
Travel with me; and to this place I brought
Her, where ſhe hath hitherto remain'd in
Perfect health, and it will be much
Advantage to her, to ſee you ſo.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I am ſorry my occaſions are of that importance
I cannot have the honour to wait upon
Her now.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Will you leave me then?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I am conſtrain'd.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Shall I have the favour of your company
To ſupper.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sir, you may depend upon the trouble.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Safety and honour ever be companion to my friend.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I am by many obligations yours.—

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Is there (you Powers) under the Heavens bright eye,
Another Lover more diſtreſs'd then I?
Mirrour of ſorrow, O what woman can
Shew more effects of love, to faithleſs man;
My Native ſoil forſook, my Parents too,
That thus diſguis'd I might be in his view▪
Once did I think his conſtancy to me,
Was as firm knit, as Faith to Charity;
But now I'm undeceiv'd, and plainly ſee,
There's no Impoſture, like Credulity.

sp.speaker: Aller.
sp.l: I will not hear one word in his excuſe;
When men perfidious in their actions grow,
What credit can we on their words beſtow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Love, Madam, is ſtill known by the effect,
In's heart methought he gave you all reſpect.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: His heart was from his tongue too much divided.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay rather ſay, your cenſure was miſguided.
A pleaſing ſubject may command your ear,
But what you like not, you are ſlow to hear;
Madam, if Caſſidore I once but name,
Your ſoul forthwith would flie into a flame.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: His Actions ever great and generous were,
Th'other a meer deluder of my ear.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Twas but an amorous untruth that you
With ſo much deteſtation ſtill purſue.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: He that would rob another of reward,
Should grieve unpitied, and lament unheard.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: This muſt be ſhe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How now, what's here?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: This is the Garden ſure, and this the Lady,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How the fellow ſtares.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I will Approach her.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: My Maſters ſervant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The brazen Head has ſpoke.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What is your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Faith Madam, a kind of an affair between
Approbation and diſlike.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: This will inform you better, Madam.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: From whom or whence?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: From a wealthy Gentleman of Sicorell,
Don Fernando Bertran.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I never heard of him before, return it,
I will receive none.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: How, Madam, ſlight, I had better go hang my
Self at my own charge.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, good Madam, open it, and ſee what it contains.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Well then, let his ſervant do it; he
Is better acquainted with his hand.

body.p:
My Child, I have 6042 Duckets a year, and
Shall be forc'd to leave this to a Kinſman,
If I have no Children but I am told,
That if I marry you, I may have
As many as I pleaſe, I can get no nearer
You, becauſe my Mule is tyred.
Come therefore to me, with all
Poſſible haſte, for it is chargeable
Lying in an Inn, where at preſent I am;
But be ſure you veil your ſelf, for the care
Of your honour is of concern to me, and you
Ought not to ſhew your ſelf; but when I think
It fit.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Bleſs me, what kind of ſtuffe is this?
Prithee, friend, what manner of man's thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why, Madam, he is a Gallant of the times;
And though his years are a little too plentiful
Upon him, yet he wears 'em with as light a heart
As any man that has numbred ſixty and odd.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: How 〈…〉

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And yet you would hardly judge it by him,
For he ſhall drink, eat, ſwear, talk and take
Tobaccho with e're a man in Sivell; Madam, I'le tell you,
He never knows woman yet, but his Houſe-keeper;
Nor Bedfellow, but a Piſtol, which he hath always
Charged, for the greatneſs of his Wealth keeps his
Cares watchful.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For a little attention, Madam, this fellow is of
A humour to tell us all.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Is he not mad?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: By my troth, Madam, you would think him ſo
Sometimes, for he is harder to pleaſe then a Mule
Is to ſhooe; and at the irregular expence of a penny,
He ſhall out-rail a month together.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mad or not mad, Madam▪ according to the avaritious
Humour of my old Maſter, if he be ſo rich as his
Servant ſays he is, it will be a hazard if he
Diſlike him.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: He ſent another Letter to your father, which I have
Delivered, and he is reading it within, giving me
Liberty in the mean time to wait on you with this.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hey day, here's like to be fine work, a Wedding agreed
Upon, and the Bridegroom unknown.
But, good Madam, let us examine this fellow
A little further.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Is he generous?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No faith, Madam, for though he has much wealth,
He is not the leſs miſerable; and truly, Madam,
To ſpeak as I ought, if your father forces him
Upon you, you'll deſerve all mens compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Thou art an honeſt open-hearted fellow,
Prithee give me thy Reaſon.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Becauſe, Madam, ſuch are the infinite number
Of diſeaſes that afflict him, he is the Practice
Of all Phyſicians; not only his Garden, but
His very Windows are ſet with Phyſick‐
Herbs, he is continually perplexed with
Fluxes, and Aches quarter in every bone of
Him; then he is as obſtinate as a devil, and as
Mutinous as Tow; a moſt abominable Sloven,
Yet as crafty as a Fox, and as malicious as a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Why this is monſtrous.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And as for his knowledge, Madam, never any came
Near it, he makes a thouſand ſecrets of nothing:
He is expreſly devoted too; for he keeps abſtinence
All the year at home, and all that live with him
Are as poor as Church-Rats.—

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I ſhould forgive all this, if he had but wit.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Wit, Madam, he abounds in that; he writes Plays.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: That's but an idle way to ſhew it,
His folly finds an increaſe in that.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And ſo good a fellow, I have ſeen him
Make himſelf ſick with his own debaucherie:
That he might have the pleaſure next day
Of taking Phyſick.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What a faithful ſervant is this?
Your father comes; for fear of the worſt, feign a Diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What, in fears, daughter?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I muſt be ever ſo, till you revoke the
Sentence of your Will; Alas Sir, you would wed
Me to a Grave; a man ſo old that he has
Forgot his Original.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The better; thou wilt be the ſooner
Poſſeſſor of his wealth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Do not ſubmit, Madam, Keep your ſelf
Still in the Negative.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Beſides, his ſervant here deſcribes him for a fool.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: No matter, the better for a husband ſtill,
The fool is cover'd with bags.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: But if the mind (Sir) be unſatisfied, wealth
Is of ſmall importance, a fool is but the
Image of a man, and yet but ill made neither.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come, come, diſpute it not, I'le have you marry,
And rid the Summer of your Youth, from all
The Gawdy Flies lie Sunning in it, hear
But the Contract, which he hath ſent me by
His ſervant—read it,

body.p:
Know all men by theſe Preſents, that Don
Fernando Bartran of Seggaral, hath appear'd
Before us, and of his good will, without conſtraint,
Doth acknowledge to take to wife Dona Alleria,
Daughter to Don Arnaldo Robatzy, of
The City of Sivil, with all her faults, Good
Or bad, and to reſtore her to him again,
Whenever ſhe ſhall be demanded of him,
By Nullity of Fact.
body.closer:
In Witneſs whereof
We have hereunto ſet our Hands and Seals, At Toledo this tenth day of Octob. 1670.
Gonſalvo Vego
Domingo Sancho
Notaries.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What would you have me think of this, can
There be greater demonſtrations of his folly.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: However, I am reſolv'd to ſee him; Friend, you
May tell your Maſter, I ſhall not part with my
Daughter upon ſuch eaſie termes as he
Imagines, if he pleaſe to extend his Journey
Hither, we may talk further on't; but Wealth
Hath no eſteem with me, not joyn'd with underſtanding.
Come, Daughter.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Well, here's a long journey taken to a ſhort
Purpoſe; but I'le to him, and tell him, there
Is hopes though there be none; at leaſt there
May be pleaſure, though no profit in the Caſe;
For his follies, where're he comes, ſtill we find,
That Mirth's moſt pleaſant that is leaſt deſign'd.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Alleria and Jaccinta, Julia and Livia, as in Jaccinta's Garden.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: MAdam, the Garden-gate let's you out the
Back-way to your own houſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am well inſtructed in the way, Madam,
And therefore pray return.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Pray ſuffer a little further my attendance.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Indeed I muſt not, Ceremon'es are never known
Where friendſhip governs.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well, Madam, ſince you will have it ſo,
I will go no further; Your ſervant,

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: But before I leave you, let me remind you
Of your Promiſe, that you will henceforth forbid
The Viſits of Caſſidore.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I have already aſſured you, that I have no
Eſteem for him; and that I ever held his
Importunities as troubleſom; but Madam.
If you expect me juſt to you in this: I
Shall requeſt you will ſhew ſome pity to
My brother, though it be feign'd, only
To prevent deſpair, ſince I have acquainted
You with his Complaints of your hard uſage.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O there they are.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: You had beſt withdraw, Sir, leſt your Appearance.
Interrupt thoſe hopes your Siſters Interceſſion
Makes.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: 'Tis well counſel'd; well, ſtand aſide, and overhear 'em.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: If that his faith be conſcious of a blot,
Abandon him your thoughts, and ſpare him not;
Or if he did to any other bow,
Or that his heart has ſtarted from its Vow;
Then curſe him, Madam, curſe him to my face,
And make me witneſs to his juſt diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Well, Madam, for your ſake I will receive
Him better, for I am without return, Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I was ever yours.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Look, Madam, your Brother has met with her there.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Madam, if my Tongue did not fear to offend,
It would offer it ſelf a Mediator for a paſſion,
So much the more inſuppreſſible for being ſecret.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: If you knew, Signior, who this habit cover'd,
Your heart would ſoon repent, to have
Allow'd your tongue this liberty.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: My heart, Madam, receives not its deſires
From blind imagination, but dictates to my
Faith, who tis I worſhip; ſo that Judgment
Acts in me, what fancy only works in others.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Your deſires move not with your Reaſon, can you
Think, whilſt you contribute to my diſturbance,
You advance your Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thoſe Idea's that are long in ſetling, are as
Uneaſily defac'd: had my Paſſion harbour'd
Any deſires oppoſite to your vertue, then with Juſtice
You might have detected it as criminal.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: O ſmooth-tongu'd Diſſembler.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Such is the nature of my love, I count
It ſin to murmure; I honour even your cruelty,
And will qualifie it with the name of Juſtice;
Your opinion of me ſhall be what you pleaſe,
So it may content you, I am willing to
Undergo all you would have me ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Behold, Madam, how devout he is, half ſo
Much ſaid to me would ha' diſſolv'd me long ago.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: If you would merit better uſage, reſtrain
Your Paſſion; and avoid my ſight, be wiſe,
And let me live in Peace.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now could I curſe my ſelf for being of her ſex:

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Thus are your ſecond Proteſtations blaſted
By the example of the firſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: All my complaints are made unto a Rock.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Why do you not reſiſt the evil then, that
Fights againſt you.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Methought her very anger look'd a little
Graceful; I'le follow her, and have the pleaſure
Of her ſight; what though a Tree be guarded
From my touch; there's none can hinder
Me to love the fruit.
Fortune's a blind Diſpoſer of her own,
Too much ſhe gives to ſome, to others none.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: He blames the tempeſt, yet embraces ſtill the Ocean.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Froward Woman.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Inflexible creature.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: She had better have been leſs rigorous.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Madam, I'le ſhew you a way to be reveng'd,
One kind look beſtowed on Caſſidore, in view
Of her, would make her frantick.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I Approve thy Counſel.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Perhaps, Madam, you have reaſon for it, for
Though he is undoubtedly handſom in her eye,
I gueſs he is not much otherwiſe in yours:
Howe're you draw the Veyl between you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I, I deſpiſe the Trophies of anothers Conqueſt,
No, Livia, if I durſt ſpeak my mind.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: What would you ſay, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Canſt thou conceal a ſecret?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, as long as it is one, but when
Two know it, how can it be a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: If thoſe two have but one heart, ah
Livia, how very fain I would without a naming
Of it be underſtood.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: If you are aſham'd to name it, you may be
As well aſham'd to ask my ſecrecie.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Canſt thou not hit my thoughts then, my
Watchful fancie would have conceiv'd thee,
If thou hadſt ſaid but half ſo much to me.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Since you will have me then ſo bold to judge;
Confeſs, Madam, has not Flaminio, the lovely
Stranger, a little touch'd your heart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: My heart?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You reſent it as if it were a crime.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: It is a crime to count that love, that ſcarce
Is an eſteem.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Come, come, Madam, 'twixt eſteem and love, there's
So much ſympathy, they are often taken
One for another.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: The Civilities I ſhew him are for my brothers ſake;

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You'll pardon me, Madam, if I gueſs this, but
A counterfeit ſelf-denial, for I obſerv'd
Laſt night (when he ſup'd with you) a ſtrange
Kind of dotage in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Prithee tell me, what could'ſt thou gueſs, from
What he ſaid or did?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: What care you take to know what you moſt
Know, your Curioſity in this gives increaſe
To my ſuſpition; Jealouſie was ever the
Iſſue of love—
But, look Madam: ſee where he comes,
Now we'll put it to the proof.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Alas, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Let us be gone, he does not ſee us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, no, I'le lie down under that fountain, and
Feign my ſelf aſleep.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Is it not as I told you, Madam, we women are
Weak paper-walls; the leaſt puff blowes us
Down; Well, nothing o'rethrows our Sex but In-
Diſcretion; we might do as well elſe (of
A brittle people,) as any under Heaven, but
What deſign is this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Withdraw, and thou ſhalt know anon.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Her tender Modeſty is a little Sea-ſick only.
A Qualm of Honour, but there's one will cure her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Robatzy being abſent, I will walk here,
Expecting his return,—ha, what Angle cloth'd
In fleſh and blood is this: O, 'tis Jaccinta: Wonder
Of Wonders; She that keeps all waking, lies
Sleeping here; Dear Object of my Joys
And cares, (in whom alone all ſweetneſs
Dwells) permit me a little to divulge the
Birth and Progreſs of thoſe pains you have created,
And ſuffer me,
Without offence to pay the devotions due to ſo
Bright a luſtre.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Flaminio?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ha, Rigorous Fate.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What ſays ſhe?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: We both love with equal flame.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O happineſs unbelievable.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Excuſe my bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Perfections great Exchecquer.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: When ſhall our pains end?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I have not power to contain my ſelf,
sp.stage: [He kneels and kiſſes her hand twice.
sp.l: So ſmells the flower of a blooming clove,
The more I drink, the more I thirſt.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Some God protect me, who is this?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What have I done, a curſe upon my raſhneſs.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What motive could excite you (Sir) to a preſumption
So uncivil.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Love, Madam, extremity of love.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Love never begets rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Love in exceſs, acts nothing elſe but what is irregular
And diſorderly; it was my Gratitude I was
About to pay.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Your Gratitude, for what?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: —What ſhall I ſay?
Madam, it was my tranſports led me to this place.
Had I lov'd leſs, I ſhould ha' bin leſs rude;
But Circumſpection ſuits not with exceſs of paſſion.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Can it be imagined you had a love for me, and
Have ſo little regard to my repoſe; if you
Were juſt to your own, you would not ruine mine.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Had you ſtill ſlept, my crime had been unknown;
But if I muſt ſuffer your rebuke for what I
Could not help, let me beſeech you ſhew
It with all the mildneſs an innocent Offender may deſerve;
Heaven knows it was a deſignleſs frailtie.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He charms me ſo, I find a pain to be unkind.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Thoſe thoughts that put me upon this confidence,
Aſpir'd too high to be ſuppreſs'd; I have kept 'em
Cover'd many tedious years; and had power
To keep them undiſclos'd another houre.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: To credit you, were to create a ſuppoſition of
Too much eaſineſs, in being led too ſuddenly
So far towards your deſires.

div.stage: [Offers to go, and he ſtays her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You keep my heart in chains, and muſt not
Go, till you releaſe it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Thus confin'd, I am your priſoner.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: We'll both be freed together then, or ſtay ſtill
By it, ſo is captivity pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What is it you would have?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Your love, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis not in my power to diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I underſtand you, Madam, in your dark replies,
Suffer me to attend you to your Brother, and I will ſhew you
Proofs, he has a favour for me,
Greater then your imagination knows.

div.stage: [He is leading her off and is met by Caſſidore.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Madam, may I receive the honour of your ſervice,
You have a hand yet free.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I want not your aſſiſtance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Let me but whiſper a ſecret in your ear, a ſecret
Of importance.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nothing is ſo important as good manners.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: The Lady is in the right, Sir, you take an ill time
To tell ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I come not hither, Sir, to learn Inſtructions of you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: But I uſe to give 'em, Sir, to ſuch as want.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Your Inſtruction, Sir, is bold and inſolent.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Oblige me then but to reject his ſervice.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: If ſhe ſhould yield to your Counſel, Sir, your life
Were in ſome danger.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: He that has confidence to withſtand his diſpleaſure,
Can never want courage to deſpiſe your reſign:
That hand thou haſt too little right to, and ſhe
Shall ſoon ſee which of us is moſt fearleſs.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I will not wrong my happineſs ſo much,
This hand would make a Tygre meek.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No man is wrong'd, now no man is Poſſeſſor.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Unhappy fruſtration, Good Madam, to ſuppreſs
His Arrogance, be pleaſ'd to declare, did you
Recal your favour in reſpect to his deſires, or not.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What's that to either of you, to whom I ſtand averſe.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Nay, gracious Madam, do not conſtrain your liberty.
To favour me: rather expoſe me to the fury of
Your frowns, then make me Author of your leaſt
Inquietudes: you ſhall ſee, Madam, my reſpects
O'recome my jealouſie: I'le patiently retire, and
Wait a time for my revenge.
But, Madam, let it not be forgotten, with what regret
I leave your Preſence, being an effect of my obedience.
Not of my deſire.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I had forgot to ask her when Caſſidore was
With her laſt.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O are you there, now to revenge my Brother:
Caſſidore, come back,

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: My abſence may oblige you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: If you eſteem my love, come back, come
Give me your hand; I did but chide in jeſt,
The beſt Lovers uſe it; it ſets an edge
Upon affection: when we invite our friends
Unto a Feaſt, 'tis not all Sweet-meats that we
Set before 'em.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Ha, I ſuſpect this ſudden change; but
I'le make uſe of an Expedient to diſtinguiſh it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Horrour to my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O monſtrous, yonder he is with her, Madam.
And ſhe ſuffers him to lead her.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I am ſeiz'd with ſuch a Feavor on the ſudden,
That the ground I ſtand on trembles under me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: But four words with you, Madam:

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I muſt not, reaſon and duty otherwiſe oblige.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: The tempeſt of a thouſand anguiſhes torment me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Reaſon and Duty otherwiſe oblige.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: O woman, woman, thy Vows are ropes of ſand,
And ſlight as webs that ſpiders weave,
Inſpire me fury, I'le be reveng'd if I have breath.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So here's like to be fine work: I'le be the
Match to this wild-fire.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now I perceive all her reſpects are counterfeit,
When ſhe diſpenc'd her favour to me, 'twas
With that neglect, as Charity is diſpos'd out
Of a Palſie hand; rather let fall then given.

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: Sir, Signior Robatzy is this way approaching to
Salute you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I will prevent him that labour;
I'le wait on him.

div.stage: [Exit and enter preſently, whilſt the Scene changes to Robat' houſe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What conſolation, Sir, have I to ſee you here
In health: your father and I held an entire friendſhip;
I hope it may be continu'd in his ſon.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I ſhall be honour'd, Sir, to be your Servant; my Mother
Commanded my delivery of ſome Letters to you,
Which in your abſence, laſt night, I left at
Your houſe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have received them, and find you have been exact
To her Appointment.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: She writ to me to Florence (where ſince my
Fathers death I have reſided with my Uncle)
That ſhe had a purpoſe to be in Spain
About this time, and with an unuſual importunity
Required me to meet her here, aſſuring me
I ſhould expect her at your houſe, but
The occaſion is to me unknown.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: She writes to me likewiſe, ſhe will be here
Her ſelf about this time.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: My Siſter, I hope, comes with her.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am not of that belief.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I muſt not ſatisfie you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Muſt not; your cloudy Language makes me
Fear Misfortune; I doubt ſhe is not living.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Her death, Sir, is not the thing that ſhould
Afflict you moſt.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Something worſe.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I am in the dark ſtill, ſtill further from your meaning:
Why was I appointed to make ſuch Haſte
Hither.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am forbid to tell you any thing; your Mother
Doth conjure my ſecrecie: tomorrow from her own mouth
You will be fully inform'd; till when, pray
Command my houſe, and all it can afford to
Expreſs your welcom.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you for your generous offer, but I
Deſire to be diſpenc'd with for this night.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: To give a Viſit to an ancient friend, and
School-fellow, who by great fortune yeſterday
I met in the ſtreet, ſoon after my Arrival,
One Don Alvarez.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alvarez, what fatal charmes oblige you to receive
The favour of an enemie; have you forgot the
Inveterate hatred that has ſo long dwelt
In both your Families.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: No, Sir, I well remember it; but that variance
Expir'd with our fathers; he ſav'd my life once
In Florence, when 'twas overwhelm'd with
Peril; and ſince my Arrival here he has
Received me, with marks of higheſt favour, allowing
Me the honour to renew my Acquaintance to his fair Siſter,
Whom (if Heaven be propitious to my wiſh)
I intend—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: All Powers above forbid it; O Sir, perſiſt not in
A deſtructive hope: your ruine's nouriſh'd in
That thought.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You have expreſs'd words of a moſt dangerous
Senſe, and if your purpoſes be not ſuddenly reverſ'd,
You are loſt for ever.
If you owe any obedience to a Mothers will,
Withdraw your reſolution.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: My ingratitude would defile my blood, ſhould
I be leſs ſenſible of his favours, benefits ſo
Multipli'd would animate the moſt ingrateful
To an Acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What power our Paſſions have over our Wills, we▪
Are all naturally ſo obſtinate againſt our good;
That though at Sea we ſuffer ſhipwrack, and in
Warre are overcome; yet we give not over neither.

div.stage: Enter Don Bertran, Sancho and Pedro.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Come Sir, we are at length Arriv'd; this is the houſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hold Sancho, thou goeſt too faſt for me: the Devil
Take this Mule, what a damn'd Trot ſhe went;
I am as ſore as if I had been cudgel'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I am glad on't: you have often put me into that
Condition, I thank your Worſhips hands for it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What's here?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I have ſcarce a whole bone left.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Fie, Sir, do not complain ſo loud, you
Should own no pain ſo near your Myſtriſs
But that of love.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You had better ha' bin horſ'd upon one of your
Flanders Mares.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: On my life, this is the old Amoriſt, that comes▪
A wooing to my Daughter; Go, call her, Addibar;

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well, what ſaid ſhe to my Letter?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why, ſhe eſteem'd it above her breath;
You are the happieſt man living, ſhe is a
Whole Mint of vertue: beſides, Sir, ſhe is young,
Fair, witty, modeſt, tall, ſlender, and a thouſand
Other things.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But does ſhe love me?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Infinitely, You do not love yonr ſelf ſo much.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And—.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Look you, Sir, here's her father come to
Meet you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why doſt thou ſhew him me? thou
Know'ſt I could never endure an old man in my life;
But ſince he's here, I'le ſpeak to him;
Father-in-law, come hither.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, my obſervation has inſtructed me who you are:
And in Teſtimony of your welcom—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay, nay, no Complement: I am a man of few words.
I underſtand your Daughter is marriageable, handſom
I am told too; for the fame of her fills Toledo, and—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Bleſs us, good Madam, what a thing is this?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: More out of faſhion then he that wants an Oath.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Her will, Sir, is limited to mine, and I would have
Her place her affections, where ſhe may
Find felicity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I can ſpeak to her then as I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Without queſtion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And my diſcourſe, you think, will pleaſe her.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have no reaſon to ſuſpect it, Sir, look Sir,
There ſhe is, you have liberty to try her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Very well, Sancho, Pedro.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Is nothing amiſs about me:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: All in very good order: only your Ruff, Sir,
Is not in the faſhion here in Sivil.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: But yet your ſhape is graceful.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The faſhion, tell me of the faſhion;
I'le be a faſhion to a faſhion, faſhion, ſayſt thou,
He that has wit is never out of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I, I, Sir; the Sun is ſufficiently beautified
With its own Rays.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Horrid impertinence: this is ſome ſtuff'd thing
Or out-ſide of a man.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nay Sir, if you wonder at this, what will
Becom of you anon, he is able to ſpeak
More with eaſe, then any man can endure
With patience.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well, Madam, either you are very handſom
Or very ugly: if ugly, you muſt ſhew your Im-
Perfections only to me: if handſom, I have
Reaſon to ſuſpect the frailty of your Sex;
So that be you handſom, or be you ugly,
'Tis requiſite you keep your ſelf veyl'd.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: VVhat Anſwer ſhall I make to ſo much folly?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: That was well hit yfaith.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: She had need be a good Horſewoman
That my Rhetorick will not diſmount:
Ho, father-in-law, ſhe does not anſwer
VVhat's the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alas, Sir, ſhe fears to ſin againſt Modeſty.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The joy of her exalted fortune throws her
Into a thouſand extaſies.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: How the fool fats himſelf with hopes,
And toils as much as if his Cards was wiſe ones.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What will you be ſtill ſilent (fair one:)
Come, I muſt have you talk to me: a woman's
Nothing, if ſhe want a tongue: away with this
Sullen humour, 'tis too cold for my deſires; Come, I
Say, I muſt have you brisk, lovely, and higher-wing'd.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Silence, Sir, is the effect of Admiration.
The nobleneſs of your deport, and generous behaviour
So much aſtoniſhes my unwary ſence, I know
Not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hah Sancho, ſhe talks well.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I was taught to admire you, Sir, before I ſaw you,
By the Rhetorique of your Amorous lines: your
Eloquent tongue is as powerful as Orpheus
Harp, and would like that, make ſtones flie.
About your ears.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A witty Rogue, ſhe has prickt his folly in
The right vein.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I find ſhe has too much wit to be ugly;
Sirrah Sancho, cauſe her to be unveyl'd, 'tis
Time to let me ſee her ſhape and aſpect.

sp.speaker: Aller.
sp.l: Sir, it belongs to me to obey, ſince your ordain it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you here, old man; I know not what Pattern
You had; but you have ſucceeded well, ſhe
Is handſom.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Your Approbation, Sir, is an honour to her:
Will it pleaſe you walk in?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I like her forehead well, and the rouling of her eye;
O thou Hive of ſweetneſs, thou Model of
Perfection, think not the worſe of me,
Becauſe I do not kiſs thee; I will not make
Thy Courteſies ſo common: Sancho, bid her be
Veyl'd agen: Nay, do it, or I'le not ſpeak a
Word more.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Sir, I know my duty, and ſhall meet you
In all commands.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O that I had but liberty to laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you hear, father; you have inſtructed
Her well: I commend your care; well my
Child, thou ſhalt ſee, I'le make thee the
Beſt wife in Sivil.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Sir, not knowing what a husband is, nor what he
May be, I can promiſe little.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay, never fear a quiet Union, I am as
Eaſily pleaſ'd as a child, let me but ſleep
I'le ne're diſturb you; Do you hear my
Little Rogue: you my little Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You give me fine names, Signior; Rogue and Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well, well, its no matter for that, its
Common with me to abuſe them I love moſt:
Get the Bride ready betimes tomorrow. I ſhall
Make ſhort work on't; I love to be brief,
Becauſe I love to be plain; or (hark you)
Now I think on't better; let us all to bed with
Our clothes on: ſo we ſhall be the ſooner ready
In the Morning.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What Company, Sir, will your Worſhip have to dinner
With you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Company, Hang Company; I'le have no Company,
I do not intend to be undone
At a meal; Come, my Spouſe, give me your hand:
Tomorrow early all that will ſhall ſee,
The Ship launch'd forth of your Virginity,
And man'd by none but me.
The more I look on thee, the more I prove;
There's ſtill more cauſe why I thee more ſhould love.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: THE night approaches, and 'tis time to put this
Letter, and my hopes into thy hands.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: What torments my diligence draws upon my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Haſten the delivery: I ſhall expect thee
With impatience.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: 'Tis not in the power of my ſenſe to diſſwade
Him from this laſt Attempt; we are all to
Our own opinions as Mothers to their children,
Loving to thoſe that merit leaſt:
Who now beholds me, cannot chooſe but ſee
An unmatch'd Mirrour of calamity.
To do my duty is to increaſe my grief,
And proſecute a Fate has no relief:
You Gods, if I muſt live miſerable, why ſhould
I be my ſelf the unhappy cauſe, and
Preſs the effect, of what I moſt ſhould fear;
See where ſhe walks: O ſtrange event of fate.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Was there ever ſuch a Phantaſtick at
His years; I know not what to make of him,
A thing between a Cradle and a Grave.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am glad my old Maſter perceives his folly;
It may be a good Omen, Madam: 6000 Duckets
A year, had once a good digeſtion with him.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: I dare not make my Addreſs, yet dare not be
Unfaithful.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: But yet my thoughts are troubled at Jaccinta's
Falſeneſs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis not without reaſon, Madam: for inſtead of
Denying Caſſidore's Viſits, ſhe preferr'd his
Service before anothers.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: After ſo firm a Promiſe too.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Madam, I am commanded to preſent this to your
Fair Hands.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: From the moſt paſſionate Adorer of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Though I know him to be Alvarez ſervant, I will
Perſwade her otherwiſe, till ſhe has read the Letter;
Perhaps it may a little mollifie.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Who ſhould this be?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: On my life, Madam, it is the Character of Caſſidore,
A Hand worth your heart, I am acquainted with it;
Come, come, peruſe it; a Lovers hand is not to be rejected.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What would this Ingrateful have?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: He begs, Madam, that at your feet he may receive
His Pardon or his Death.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: His Death I ſeek not, let him hope and live,

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: O fatal Clemency!
Madam, he owns 'tis guilt enough in him, that
You ſuſpect him guilty▪ but the Offerings of the
Penitent, make the offended Gods relent

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I am pleaſ'd at this ſubmiſſion

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: [aſide. I fear you will not be ſo long.

body.p:
Though I ſuſpect my Addreſs to be offenſive, yet
I ſhould not be obedient to my heart, if I did not
Proſecute its will; let me implore you therefore to
Accept of my ••• trition, and withdraw the Impreſſions of
That cruelty, that Winter ſtarves the happineſs of

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Alvarez: Pernicious man, is it from him?
How were my hopes miſled?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: What diſmal change is this?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: My thoughts did preacquaint me with this iſſue.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Madam, to inſult upon a proſtrate wretch, is
Harder tyranny, then to have made him ſo.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: He is as hateful to my ſoul, as ſin unto the Saints.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So Tygres, at the hearing of ſoft Muſick,
Become more cruel.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: So ſick men riſe and hunt, for what Phyſicians
Do deny 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange, a man ſhould be ſo conſtant under
Such diſdains.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I would acknowledge it a vertue in any other,
But in him a fooliſh dotage of the mind.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This Paſſion meaſures all things by it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Give me a Lover that would rather die, then that
The world ſhould know he is ſick:
Theſe punings and theſe whinings I abominate.

div.stage: Enter Caſſidore leading and courting Jaccinta.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How can a juſt grief contain it ſelf, when
There is ſo much cauſe for a Complaint.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Soft, who are thoſe

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: By this good Evening, Madam, 'tis Caſſidore
Courting of Jaccinta.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What's this that pains my heart o'th' ſudden ſo.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I can tell you, Madam: 'tis love, the fineſt ſickneſs
In the world, when it take two together▪

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Oh, faireſt Lady, faireſt of thouſands your bluſh
Is like the morning: and your ſmile brighter then noon.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What would Alleria ſay, if ſhe ſhould hear this?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: In theſe armes I'le lock you faſt for ever, and ſooner
Part from all the World, then from my joys in you.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: O that my eyes were into Bullets turn'd,
That I might ſhoot 'em at his heart.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: The vertuous heat that ſojourns in this •• nd,
Chaſeth my active ſpirits through my veins,
In ſuch a wanton dalliance, as if pleaſure in me
Had proclaim'd a Jubilee.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Patience, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Out of Call, I warrant you: ha, the sky grows
Overcaſt; help, help, help, O my Lady:

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: How now, what cry is that?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O curſed man: you are the unhappy cauſe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Alleria: and in a Swoon; I have a Balſom (chaf'd
Upon her temples) will recover her in an inſtant.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O you tyrant, you hard-hearted man, is this fit
Uſage to a Lady? has all your feign'd reſpects to her
Brought forth this fruit?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: What ſhall I do? unhappy accident.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have no way to recompence her, but by
Putting on an Artificial Penitence.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Hear me, thou faireſt Idol of the eye, behold
What torments does oppreſs my ſoul, to ſee
The light of thoſe bright Suns eclipſ'd.
The day has no eſteem, but for thy ſake.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What pretty flattering ſtuff theſe men are made of?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Hear but my mournful Sighs▪ the beſt Expreſſors
O a heavy ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Amazement ſeize me, what do I behold; all the
Diſtruſts that are paſt, at this one Object return
To thicken this black vapour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So, now it happens as I deſign'd.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I love you ſecretly, my Humility will witneſs
The truth of my reſpects; this that you have conſtrued
As a wandring from my Allegiance, is but a
Feign'd Civility.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: To what remote unhabitable place of the earth
Is the faith of mankind fled?—thou haſt now
Unveyl'd the black diſguiſe cloth'd thy falſe ſoul.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Madam.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, never ſeek for an excuſe,
For now another ſhall enjoy the heart thou haſt
So much abus'd; I'le give it unto one declares he hates me.
E're thou ſhalt be Poſſeſſor of it, and ſo take
Vengeance on my ſelf for my too eaſie faith.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Why, Madam, are you thus offended, for a
Fault committed by my tongue, and not my heart;
Your Jealouſie is unjuſtly alarm'd, all that I
Have ſaid is counterfeit, on purpoſe to delude
Her, from ſuſpecting of my faith to you.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: O Traitor, canſt thou with bluſh-leſs impudence
Declare ſo much to her?—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I thought we ſhould have change of weather,
The Moon hung ſo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Perfidious, now declare thy ſelf, to which of us
Is thy baſe heart inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Pull off your Mask, you ſhall diſſemble no
More.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I ſhould leſs pity him, had he 30 Bayliffs
At his heels.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Speak then, to which of us is thy love given,
Perjur'd man?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: So the aſſembled Clouds do meet and poure
Their long collected fury in one ſhoure.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Unfaithful, is it to me:

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Am I the Object of your love?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Am I that of your hate!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I never till now ſaw a ſoul in Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Deceiver.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Flatterer.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Double ſoul, and without faith.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Promiſe-breaker.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Oh Heavens: has the ſimplicity of my reſpect
Begot this iſſue.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Couſener; you love me.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I do; may my hopes accordingly be bleſt.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I adore you with my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Thou canſt divide thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: O inſolence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He is courted with that variety; his appetite
Stands Newter.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I am devoted to you both; the honouring her
Merit, is doing homage to yours: you are both
Fair, and it will be injuſtice to one of you
To tell you more.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Come back, or I'le abjure thy ſight for ever.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Come back, I ſay, and put an end to this diſpute—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pray Madam, hear me.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Madam, for Heavens ſake permit me to diſguiſe
My diſeſteem for her in words, which I beſeech you
Credit as the true meaning of my ſoul to you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Alas, Madam, how would you have him govern himſelf
In ſuch Surprizes: of neceſſity, he muſt flatter
One, to preſetve his intereſt in the other.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Madam, if I have ſaid any thing diſpleaſing, let
Your diſcretion tell you, how much I was ſurpriz'd,
And wooe you to a forgiveneſs: is it poſſible, you
Should have greater proofs of my affection, then
What I have already given, you know, ſhe loves
Me not, and ſhe has told you ſo; and to aſſure you
My Integrity is more to you then to her; I'le give
You (in her hearing) the Pledge of all my ſoul
To witneſs, that I will never court her more.
Only ſuffer me, by that reſpect I pay unto her
Brother, to wait upon her back; in common
Civility I am oblig • d to that.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: How I may truſt him now, I cannot tell,
But he has a ſtrange power over me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So the congeal'd vapour melts again: I'le
After her, and yet diſſwade her from any good
Opinion of him.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Come, Madam, have I not well feigned?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: —You have—but yet it ſhall
sp.stage: [Alle. and Jul. appearing in her Chamber
sp.l: Not profit you.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: O Madam: if you love your peace, be gone from
Hence: My Maſter is almoſt frantick with jealouſie,
Only by the power of a dream:
He heard the voice of a man, as he thought,
In your Chamber,
And is beyond all remedy Lunatick, his rage
Is hotter then the dog-days.

div.stage: Enter Bertran with his Night-Cap and Swerd drawn.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ho, who's there? what are you? ſpeak; bring lights there

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Hark, do you hear his bellowing?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Where are you? ſpeak, tell me: ha: nay, if you 'ſcape
Me, the Devil's in't; I will diſpeople all the earth,
And drown the World in blood but I will find him.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: How ſhall we do to 'ſcape the torture of his frenzy.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Fear not, Madam, retire to your Chamber, and
I'le keep him in talk till you get out.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What voice is that, ſpeak, or I will chop
A Leg of: by my vext ſoul I'le make thee
A Break-faſt for the Crows.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Pray Sir, be patient; I am your Servant Sancho.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O is it you, you are a pretty Raſcal, Sirrah,
To be up with my Spouſe at this time of night.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The care of your honour, Sir, mov'd me to be
Watchful, that none might wrong your love.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O I thank you, Sir, you are careful of my honour
Sirrah, who the Pox committed that care
To your charge: you Trencher-ſlave, I'le kick thee,
Till thou haſt no more feeling then a Jews conſcience,

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Who the Devil would ſerve a man, to be
Thus abuſ'd.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, muttereſt thou?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I am ſure I have deſerv'd better.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Still muttereſt thou?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: But I ſee I muſt endure it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yet muttereſt thou?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So do fat dogs worry the lean.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sirrah, villain, ſlave, dog, toad, whelp, what
Sayſt thou? by this Hilt, I'le rip up each vein
And ſinew of thy heart, if thou doſt not tell
Me what this noiſe was?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why, why, why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Quick, quick, you Hound: I ſhall be made
Ridiculous, the ſcoffe and laughter of the World.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, what a Phlegmatick fool is this?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Good Sir, be more temperate; I would not for
My hand, the Houſe here ſhould perceive one
Of your years and gravity to be—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, my years and gravity: why you thin-gutted
Slave, how old am I: I am not rotten yet,
Nor grown ſo Ranck, to ſmell o'th' Grave; O
Times and Manners, he takes me for a hollow Trunck,
A Carcaſs, a Tomb, a Sepulcher.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: This fellow has a Babel-arrogance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Brave in the ſhop, but nothing in the ware-houſe.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why, Sir, Age is a Term may be giv'n to a Child;
I did not ſay you were old, Sir, I ſhould bely
My ſight, there are roſes in your cheeks, a quick
And active blood runs free and freſh, through
Every vein.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now he makes a boy of me; a very ſtripling
School-boy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I had beſt help to quiet him, Madam; leſt my
Maſter over-hear us: and a worſe thing happen.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Still you take all things worſe then they are
Meant, Sir, you are ſo jealaous.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Jealous, I have not cauſe for it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For pity ſake, fret not your Maſter thus:—
Pray Sir, be pacified.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O are you there, Huswife,
I muſt be pacified; a very Baby, an Infant.
Give me ſome Pap or Plums, buy me a Hobby-horſe
And a Rattle.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Thou haſt a hundred in thy head already.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What an overgrown Waſp is this? pray Sir, to bed,
'Tis late; what do you think 'tis a Clock?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Go look.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The sky is full of ſtars, you may know by them.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The ſtars and clocks too: tell me the
Reaſon why I am diſturb'd: tell me that.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, you diſturb your ſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Go, go, you are a pratling Houſewife; I have no more
To ſay to you: I'le go to your Myſtriſs, and know
The cauſe from her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My Myſtriſs; alas Sir, ſhe's in bed, and ſleeps
Securely.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well then, I'le go hearken if ſhe ſnores, for
I would rather lie with a Hog, then a ſnoring
Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I came from her Chamber, Sir, but now,
She is as calm as Midnight.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I'le go wake her then, for I have
A fancie to prattle with her.

sp.speaker: Jul▪
sp.l: That, Sir, were to abuſe the good opinion ſhe
Has of your breeding; and I have heard her ſay,
She believes you are very learn'd.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But believe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And vertuous.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Who knows not that?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A great Hiſtorian, and well read.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Who dares deny it?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would it not then be much unſuitable to theſe
Good Qualities, to interrupt her in her reſt.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: She tickles his vanity rarely;
Good Sir, to bed then, and take your full repoſe:
You will look ill elſe, on your Wedding-Morn:

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Away, Sirrah, you are a fool.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I do confeſs it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: An Aſs, and a Knave.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: So are my betters.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir be patient: ſprinkle water on your
Choller: You ſhall not be angry; come, you
Shall not, for my ſake be patient.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well, I am pacified: and now thou haſt pleas'd
Me, I will rehearſe to thee one of my Comedies:
That which I intend ſhall be acted the morrow
After my Wedding.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How do you call it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Herod's Slaughter of the Innocents.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: An excellent Theam as any you could have choſe.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: But that's Tragical, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hold your tongue, Sirrah; I hope I know what it
Is, that writ it: in the laſt Act I bring all
To life again.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I Sir, now you are in the right.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I have written fourty Plays, and never any
Gave me ſo much trouble, for in the firſt
Scene, I bring in: Herod with three hundred Innocents.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How Sir; O me, what a fine ſight that will be.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: If Herod have any Attendants, the Stage will
Be pretty well fill'd.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He ſhall have his Guards, Footmen and Pages.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why Sir, that will be a little Army.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Madam, Madam, you may get by now.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha: what's that? Ho, houſe: bring lights there;
I heard ſomebody whiſper, who is it? ſpeak, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why Sir, 'twas I, was ſpeaking to your Innocents;
I was ſaying they would take up too much
Room.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You had like to have ſpoil'd all: No, no, no,
Our great Hall would hold 'em; if they were
Twice as many; but, Sir, to your ſecond Scene.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: In that I exceed belief, for juſt as the Tyrant
Is about to deſtroy 'em, I bring in—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Alas, what ſhall we do?—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Who was it call'd for lights here?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here, here, here: O my dear Myſtriſs, are you there?
I did you too much wrong to think you aſleep.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why Sir, why was there not a man ſhut up
In your Chamber, did I not hear him?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What's this you ſay?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why I ſay that you did not ſleep, there was
A certain man prevented you; what is he
Handſom, is his eye pleaſing to you, and his Noſe
Well made; are his Legs of a right Cut,
Or ſhall I cut 'em for you?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Do you only feign your ſelf mad, or are you
So indeed.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What am I, what do you make of me?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Two Queſtions, no body can Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis well, fair Madam: you eſteem me mad then,
And dare tell me ſo much unto my face;
I'le ſhew you that I am not mad, for I will
Not be deceiv'd: here, give me a light, by
Pluto's ſoul I'le find him: though he were
Above Steeples, or beneath Hell; nay, if he
Were retreated to his Mothers womb.

div.stage: [Exit in a fury, with a Candle in his hand, and ſword drawn.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I, I: Let him go, let him go; the Bear
Wants Breathing.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good Madam, take this occaſion of his abſence,
And be gone.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: 'Tis well adviſ'd, Madam, for now his Paſſion
Is up: he will diſturb you more then a Catter‐
Wauling: the 32 winds (when broken forth at
Once in oppoſition) will be ſoft Muſick to the
Noiſe he'll make.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Hark, what a rumbling he keeps:
An everlaſting hoarſeneſs dwell in his throat.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: within] Death and Furies, Muſt I be all night a hunting
You; ſpeak and ſave thy life, a man, a rogue,
A Villain, a Houſhold-thief, a Robber of my
Honour, a Spider to infect my walls, come out
You Wolf, come out here.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What a roaring does he keep.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Heark, on my life he is tumbled over ſomething.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O Sancho, Sancho, Sancho, help, help, help: bring
Me lights here, I am undone.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I muſt in and help him, he'll grieve himſelf
Sick elſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways for a vexatious old fool,
When a man is a trouble to himſelf, 'tis time
The World were rid of him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Jealouſie was ever valiant:
Well, if e're ſhe marries him, let her take my Advice;
For a revenge cuckold him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Cuckold him: 'tis ſuch a common Town-trick
She ſcorns to follow the faſhion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O Pedro, Pedro, what ſhall I do, both my Shins
Are broken againſt the frame of a ſtool.

sp.speaker: San. and Ped.
sp.l: Alas, poor Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How now, what doſt laugh?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Who I laugh, Sir; alas, not I, Sir▪ I'am griev'd
At your misfortune.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Come, come, peace, good Sancho; it cannot be help'd,
Go, Pedro, go get me ſome brown paper and a little
Honey.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A Halter and a Gallows rather.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Come Sir, put up your ſword, ſince the Rogue is
Fled for't, let the gods puniſh him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, let the devil puniſh him; he'll hamper him:
Where is this Quean? ſhe can tell me what he was;
You Houſwife, Polcat, you ſoapy-Slut, what ſay you?
Where is he? what was he?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why thou bundle of diſeaſes, thou yelping devil;
Where doſt thou think thou art, thou tun of
Naſtineſs: were not poiſon to thee natural, thy
Own rottenneſs would ſtrangle thee: O that
Thy eyes were worth the pulling out.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Well ſaid, at him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, Sanc, Sanc, what ſays ſhe?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: She's mad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That Lady thy poiſonous tongue abuſes thus,
Has more vertue in her then all thy Progeny
Could ever own: Slight, were it not a ſhame
Unto humanity. I would (in reparation of her
Wrongs:) Kick thy fat Lump into its Grave,
Force thee to creep into thy Scabbard, and make
Thee with thy own hands ſtick up thy bellowing
Chaps.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Well done, faith Girle, here's a Virago for you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay, nay, nay, I am ſatisfied my Spouſe
Is honeſt, prithee, good Wench, hold thy tongue,
And make no words on't; I will believe the
Noiſe I heard was in the next houſe, or any
Thing elſe that thou would'ſt have me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: VVhy ſo, Sir, now it is as it ſhould be: this
Temper does become you: a Husband ſhould
Be always credulous of his VVives honeſty,
Though he has no reaſon for't, the VVorld will
Count him a good-natur'd man; I will go
Tell my Lady now what a good-natur'd man you
Are when you are pleas'd.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: She has hector'd him rarely: he is as calm
As a child in ſleep.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Come, Sancho, lead me to my bed, my head akes,
My ſhins are broke, my bones ſore, my ſtomack
Is faint; I am all diſordered, Heaven ſend us
VVell back again, for I'le have none of her.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Truly, Sir, it was againſt my will you took
This journey.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: VVhene're my heart (again) Love entertains,
May all the Divels in Hell forbid the baynes.

div.stage: Enter Flaminio and Addibar, with Muſick ready.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: The houſe is hereabout, go call the Muſick.

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: They are here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Bid 'em ſing the Song that I appointed under
That window, and d'ye hear, get the Maſquerade
Ready: in caſe ſhe ſhould look out.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What Muſick is this I hear?
The ſtillneſs of the night lends it a graceful eccho.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now for the Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Who is that, that dares attempt the Circumvention
Of my hopes▪ ſpeak whoe're thou art.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: My name's Flaminio.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Flaminio?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Then know I am thy mortal Enemy, Caſſidore: and
'Tis no little joy to me, that I have met thee here;
Tell me, and that ſuddenly, why thou aſſum'ſt
The liberty to court my Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: As her brothers friend ſhe ſuffers my reſpects;
If I were her Lover, doſt think me Maſter
Of no more diſcretion, then to ſatisfie my
Rival with it.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Then draw.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: As willingly as ever man met fortune.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ah—

div.stage: They figbt, Jac. ſhrieks and ſhuts the window.

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: O help, help, help, what will you do, Sir:
Maſter, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What noiſe is this, who calls for help?

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: Here, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Ha, Caſſidore, is it you?
What hath inrag'd thy blood to ſuch a fury.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Who would not die with joy in the defence of his
Affection.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: What, Flaminio, too; what divel (envious of mens
Friendſhip) ſcattered the ſeeds of this diſſention.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Dear friend, leave us to our difference.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I muſt not leave you, nor I will not.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: O 'tis a disfavour to us now.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Let me but know the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Come, Flaminio, with you I know I can prevail;
You were not wont to hide a thought from me:
Tell me, what hath drawn this foul weather in thy face?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Why, ſuppoſe he would have me quit my right
To bleſſedneſs.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Or he deprive me of that good that is invaluable.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I comprehend you not; you do not deal by me as
One whoſe love was worth your eſtimation.
I have an equal intereſt in both your fates; you are
Both my friends: neither can ſuffer, but I muſt
Share in • t: How comes it then my importunities
Find ſuch oppoſition.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: In vain, Alvarez, is this friendſhip ſhewn: my
Reſolution is but deferr'd for ſome moments, had he
The Altar for ſecurity: Religion ſhould not
Bind me from his death.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I little thought, Flaminio, you could have been
Repugnant to a Friends requeſt.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Prithee deſiſt, it is not worth thy care.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Can any thing require the Expoſure of thy life,
That bears not a value worthy of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What wouldſt thou have me tell thee,
Heavens, what an extremity is this?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Since you refuſe to tell me,
I gueſs the cauſe: you are both in love with one beauty.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Thou haſt ſurmiz'd a truth, now thou art ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: If I am, I owe no thanks to your confeſſion: yet
Oblige me, tell but her name.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O cruelty it ſelf, muſt I declare to him: it is
His Siſter.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: How ill doth this Reſerve become thee now?
I never hid from thee the ſecrets of my ſoul: thou
Wert the Cloſet to 'em all.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What can I tell him if I name her, what is it he
VVill not ſay, for I have courted her without his
Licence.
I muſt conceal it till a fitter time.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: This confuſion in him raiſes my diſtruſt. I fear
It Alleria:—What, muſt I not know her then?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: This Reluctance, friend, proceeds from certain
Fears I have, that when I have nam'd her
To you, you'll turn my enemy; and cancel that
Moſt ſacred bond of Uuion, that hath ſo long been
Seal'd between us; judge then, is it fitting I
Should tell thee any more; truſt me, Alvarez,
Thy deſires, thy deſires, ſhould find a recompence
In any thing but this:—farewel.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Heark you, Flaminio, whither are you going thus late?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I have oblig'd my ſelf, to lie this night at
Signior Robatzy's; for both of us tomorrow early
Are to meet my Mother in her way from Rome;
Good-night—

sp.speaker: Alva.
