sp.l: I am more confus'd then ever; he lies this night
At her houſe, how every thing conſpire to
Aggravate my doubts; was it for this (falſe man)
I ſav'd thy life, to ſupplant me of my hopes: O
Wolf that durſt devour the breaſt that nurs'd thee;
But he forgets, the life I gave him was but lent,
And is to be remanded at my pleaſure; I ſee
His end through all his cloſe contrivance: now I find
That open foes are eaſier to invade,
Then Ambuſhes that are in friendſhip laid.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Signior Robatzy, Flaminio and Addibar.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: IT were unfit, Sir, my Mother ſhould be attended
Only with your Company, and my ſelf here, waiting
Her Arrival.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Though 'tis your duty, Sir, it is not needful;
For 'twas her Command you ſhould expect her
At my houſe.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: My ſoul would ſuffer much diſquiet, ſhould
I omit a duty ſo becoming.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But ſhe is not aſſured of your Arrival, Sir,
Only may gueſs it by the time of her Appointment.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: So much the better, Sir, duty's perform'd, when
Unexpected renders the Surprize the greater.
Well, Sir, 'tis your Conqueſt, and I muſt yield,
We'll go together.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Addibar, Get the Coach ready, and bring it to
The Garden-gate.

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: It is all truth that I have told you, Sir, ſhe
Loaths you more then youth hates death; or age
Her ſpightful Neighbour; The Letter that
You ſent by me ſhe tore into a thouſand pieces,
And with a look ſo full of terrour, as if ſhe would
Have done as much to you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, yonder's Alvarez: Pray ſuffer me
To take my leave of him before we go.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Not for a world, Sir, pray pardon me: I muſt not
Suffer it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Your reſtraint is as unjuſt as cruel. I, ſhould I
Violate the reſpects I owe him: and without cauſe
Reject ſo dear a friend.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Who is that, Flaminio?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The more you urge me,
I am the more averſe to your deſires: Pray let us go.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: This is unnatural, Sir, thus to refuſe the
Converſation of the man I moſt eſteem.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I cannot grant it you.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Now truth's unmaſqu'd, and ſhame walketh
By, bearing a bluſhing torch; Didſt thou
Obſerve, Lyſander, with what care and trouble he
Avoided me; Doubtleſs, the remorſe of his
Ingratitude, makes him conſcious of the wrongs
He has done me, whilſt ſhe triumphs in
Her unjuſt ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Ah, my Lord, the Heavens are too impartial
To behold (with pleas'd eyes) the wickedneſs of our
Offences, and therfore prudently inflict upon us puniſhments
Ofttimes proportion'd to the nature of our crimes.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I call all nature to defiance, to accuſe me
Of a ſin qualified for ſuch a judgment.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Examine well, Sir, the actions of your life;
No breach of faith, no violation of a ſacred Vow.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: By the ſoul of truth I never.—

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Hold Sir; before you ſwear, let me diſcover
To you what ſhe told me; ſomebody in
Prejudice of your love inform'd her, that in
Italy you were contracted to a young and an
Innocent Maid, nam'd Semena, of a noble Family:
But when ſhe had given her vertue to your
Charge, exchang'd hearts, and wrap'd 'em in your
Faith: You moſt diſhonourably left her the
Ignominy and ſcandal of her ſex; and upon this
Conjecture, Sir, ſhe builds her Rigour, that he
Who changes once, may do ſo ever.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: But this was not inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Not Sir, it will be difficult to prove it other.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Fear not, I ſhall eaſily convince her of
My innocence.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Heavens, what can this Ingrateful ſay▪

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Alas, I had not ſeen that Lady that thou
Speak'ſt of, when ſhe was offred me to wife;
'Tis true, by the perſwaſion of our relations, I did
Agree to marry her, to reconcile ſome
Animoſities, that had long liv'd in both our
Families: ſo that it was not the Election
Of my Will, but the intereſt of my Peace oblig'd me to it;
Judge then how much I am wrong'd, by being
Upbraided with a crime I am not guilty of.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: My ſoul has now her full load.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Hold, yonder's a Lady veyl'd,
For ſhape and motion much reſembling Alleria.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Dear Sir, forbear, I muſt not ſuffer you;
Do you not know the cuſtom of the place?
To draw the Curtain in the ſtreet (though ſhe
Were mean) is mortal.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nothing ſhall reſtrain me:

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Your brother, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Alas, how ſhall I ſhun him?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Madam—

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: What is't would you have, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: A view of that fair Lady:
What eye can ſee you, Madam, and not carry War
Unto his heart.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Did ever man more wilfully proſecute his
Own Misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: 'Tis a felicity to me, to be within the view of my
Tormentor: My reſt, my life, my all is in your hands.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You are ill inſtructed, Sir; this is not ſhe you look for.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Not ſhe, what makes her ſhun me then?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: You ſee, you ſhoot your Arrows againſt
A Rock, which may return to hurt you.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Let me but hear her ſpeak: give me a
Word from her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Look you, Sir, what will it profit you?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: My Siſter, what treacherous Guides are our deſires:
Why did you keep my heart ſo long lock'd up in errour?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Only to try what paſſions were about it.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: But whether were your haſty ſteps directed?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, I am at my journey's end, Brother;
My ſetting forth was only bent to give you joy,
I hear you are to be married.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Ah, Siſter, my death you'll ſooner ſee,
I am injur'd above the power of ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: By whom, Brother.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: You know too well; the falſe Flaminio.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What's his crime?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: His love.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: His love?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: His treacherous love, why do you feign your ſelf
Ignorant of what you ſo well know?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O Heavens, he knows he loves me: and thence
His anger comes.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Were he hid within the Caverns of the earth,
My revenge (ſubtil as it is) ſhould find him;
And though he had a ſword tempered with charmes,
Yet would I kill him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O Brother, he's but an ill Phyſician will deſtroy
The Patient he can cure, the errours of our
Friends, we ſhould detect with admonition,
Not with rage and violence.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thou art his Advocate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Love, brother, (if it be a crime) is not always
An Act of our intention, but oftentimes we are
Surpriz'd in to it by accident, the offences therefore
That proceed from our Misfortunes, are not to
Be charg'd as the tranſgreſſions of our wills,
But rather pitied as our frailties, and excus'd.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Siſter, I approve your interceſſion, and call
It by the name of generous: I have lov'd
Him ſo, he was the Volume of my ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: How know you then but your ſuſpitions are
Unjuſt, and Innocence made guilty by a falſe ſurmize▪

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O 'tis too evident he loves her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Her, who?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Alleria.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He love Alleria.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I ſurpriz'd him even now talking with her
Father, and when he ſaw me, he ſlunk away as
Black ſouls do at the face of Juſtice: beſides,
He lay laſt night at her houſe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O flie to your revenge; let him not live a moment,
Now I curſe the raſh Compaſſion I beſtow'd upon him.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Why are you (Siſter) ſo incens'd, becauſe a Mote
Troubles your eye, would you for this pluck down
The Sun from Heaven.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: The trouble (brother) that appears in me, riſeth
From an apprehenſion of his wrongs to you;
Can there be a greater indignity imputable to
Man then breach of truſt, and that in ſacred
Friendſhip; Friendſhip did I ſay, friendſhip
Is loſt when Rivalſhip begins; Go, go, and
Puniſh in his blood the crimes of his falſe ſoul.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: What, in a Turtle's look a Tygre's mind.
He is but an ill Phyſician will deſtroy the
Patient he can cure, the errours of our friends we
Should detect with admonition, not with rage and violence.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Dull purblind frailty: as 'tis a glory to be jealous.
Of our honour, ſo 'tis an errour to wink at what
We ought to ſee.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: If it be an errour, Siſter, it was introduc'd by you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Then 'twas the ignorance of his crime made
Me ſtand up againſt the guilt, and interpoſe
Between your wrath and him; but now I do no
Longer hold you, haſte to your revenge: as many
Minutes as you defer it, ſo many wounds you
Make upon his breaſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Away, raſh woman, thou art no more alli'd
Unto my nature, then a Vulture's to a Dove.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, no, let him live then, and be the mark
Of your diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: You are inconſiderate in your paſſion: would you
Have me kill the man that's worthy of my
Mercy: perhaps my jealouſie has done him
Wrong: his love to her may be of an Elder
Growth then mine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O injurious Clemency: the life he owes you
(Were there no other cauſe) obliges him to
Reſign all Claims unto her: but he deſerves
All wrongs that can ſo tamely ſuffer the
Privation of his love.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: My Inquietudes are great, I'le take the
Recollection of ſome minute in the mean time,
Make you a Viſit to Alleria for further
Confirmation, ſhe hath well counterfeited,
But yet I ſee through the deceit:
O what a wondrous little part
Has Heaven, in a diſſembling womans heart.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I wonder, Madam, you ſhould love a man,
Yet ſeek his death with ſo much earneſtneſs.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I loath the thought of loving him: If I have
Any paſſion for him, 'tis revenge.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: That vengeance is but lame, that walks upon
The Crutches of the tongue, though
You have thundred out your fury againſt
Him, I know you would not hurt a hair
Of him for all the world▪

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O how ſhould I rejoyce to ſee an Earthquake
Gape and take him in before me: Not hurt
Him; yes, I would be as wild in my revenge
As is the Lion in full heat of blood: when by
Inſtinct he knows his Mate plays falſe.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: O Madam; I rejoyce in this good fortune:
It was you I ſought for.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And it was you I would avoid.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: At your approach my heart ſtarts out of its
Dark deſpair, and opens as Roſes at the gentle
Aſpect of the Sun: why do you uſe ſo ill, a man
So faithful.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yonder is one will give you a reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Madam, ſhe is handſom, and more kind.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What always with that deceitful: now I find
A fair occaſion for my revenge, Jaccinta: you
Appear to me ſo indiſpoſ'd; I have no
Encouragement to acquaint you with my News.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What is it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis unſeaſonable now (I find) to talk of
Masks and Revels.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: All manner of Intelligence from you is welcom.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Since you will know it then, I'le tell you: my
Father hath at length appointed me a husband.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Do you not mean the fat old Gentleman my
Brother told me of.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Out upon him for a Puff-paſt, no one that
Is youthful, nobly born, and generous: when
You know who it is, you will approve my choice.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Who is it, pray?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: You need but ſmall inſtruction, he hath
Lodg'd at your houſe: 'tis your Brothers friend.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: His name.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How willingly ſhe would hear, what ſhe unwillingly
Would know—Flaminio. Ha, ha, ha;
Now ſhe reſents my griefs.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Madam, Madam, for ſhame recal your ſelf,
And bear it bravely.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I have much intereſt in the event.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: But pray tell me, is not this change welcom to you?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: The wretched beggar could not reſent,
What greater joy ſhould he a Kingdom gain?
I count his love's the higheſt thought felicity
Can reach; and reap ſuch happineſs in his eſteem;
I want a ſubject for another wiſh.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: But does he recompence your eſteem with the
Reward that is due to it?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: He loves me more then I can expreſs;
He ſwears he lives only by the bleſſing of my eyes
When he is near me he is tranſported, but
Out of ſight, in torments: if by chance I meet
him, I fear to ſee him die with joy: and (if his
Oaths be true) not only with diſlike, but hate,
He views all other faces.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And you love him you ſay as much.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Love him: I had much rather live with him
On ſome high Mountain cover'd with ſnow,
And hung with Iſicles, then live with any
Other in Palaces, with all varieties imaginable.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You hear this, Caſſidore?

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: I do, Madam, and rejoyce to ſee her Fortunes ſwell
To your deſire.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I ſooner ſhall forget my name then my engagements
To your favours: but your inconſtancy was of an ill
Example; it ſoon taught me the way.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Pray Madam, let us mention it no more, but
Still repute me as I ever was: Your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you; Madam, at my Wedding, pray
Give me the honour of your Company▪

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You ever had commands upon your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Permit me, Madam, I beſeech you to give you
My Attendance.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: My Revenge I have, but not my hopes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, Madam?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Fortune's utmoſt ſpight purſues me▪ Caſſidore
Still flies me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You loſe nothing in the change, Madam:
Flaminio is the handſomer man in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Thou art miſtaken, Julia; I have held a falſe
Glaſs before her eyes: all this I ſaid, I feign'd,
Only to puniſh her infidelity to me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Say you ſo, Madam; now by my honeſty
It was cunningly carried.
But ſee, Madam, Caſſidore returns, and that's
No ill ſign.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What, have you ſo ſoon quitted the Idol of
Your ſoul: O, I ſee the reaſon, your looks diſcover
Some unkindneſs in her carriage to you.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: It were a wrong unto the goodneſs of her Nature,
Should I make the leaſt complaint of her ill uſage.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Come, come, unvizard your deceit: has ſhe not
Told me, ſhe deſpis'd your courtſhip, and vow'd
It was much diſlike ſhe ever ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Thoſe diſcourteſies have found a Grave long ſince.
The minute (Madam) is ſcarce paſt, in which ſhe
Gave me Promiſe of her love: and I am going
Now to ſeek her brother out for his conſent:
Your ſervant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: What have I done, how I am puniſh'd with my
Own craft; my hypocriſie hath only ſerv'd
To make her deſperate, in crediting the truth
Of my report ſhe hath given her faith to him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How could you expect it other?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I have made a Cauſway of Ice, my ſelf to walk on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good Madam.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Affliction on affliction hourly finds me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pray Madam, hear me.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Would I had bit my unhappy tongue out,
When I invented words ſo fatal to my hopes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why here's a woman right, never ſetled in one
Mind; either too mild a calm,
Or elſe too rough a ſtorm.
Well may men ſay, we are a kind of ill mixt-Nature.

div.stage: Enter Robatzy meeting Alleria and Julia.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Daughter, I have been ſeeking you, Flaminio's
Mother is arriv'd; I would have you haſte
To give her welcom.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: I ſhall attend her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Do you hear, Julia?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What ſtorm is that ſits in your Myſtriſs's brow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nothing, Sir, but perplex'd a little at the
Follies of the old lover.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Bid her think what wealth ſhe will be Myſtriſs of.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hang wealth, what does plenty ſignifie with deceaſe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why juſt ſo much as beauty with poverty.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fie, Sir, would you have her chain'd to a man,
Who divides the houres with Cofes: as Cokes do
The night, by inſtinct of Nature.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Youth, like a Hunter, when his prey is taken
Seeks for new Game, and leaves the old forſaken;
Tell her from me, Young fruits the ſtomack gripe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And thoſe do ſurfet that are over-ripe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: within. Ho, where are you father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Heark, Sir, the Hunt's up, you hear the cry: I'le
Be gone. If I ſtay I ſhall have the Head-ach
Three days after.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: She is in the right, for he drops out of his
Mouth in an houre, whatſoever is pour'd in at
His ears in a day.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O old man, are you there?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I Sir, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What did you hear any thing of the noiſe laſt night?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: No, Sir, I heard nothing.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No faith, I believe thee; if the Fire ſhould
Burn your houſe down; you would be roaſted like
A Woodcock in't, before you would 'ſcape it.
Lord, Lord, what ill ears have theſe old fellows: but
Though you are ſo damnable drowſie, you
Have a daughter watchful enough.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, what was the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Firſt, tell me, have you a mind to hear me?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: With all my heart, I am prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Ber,
sp.l: Well, I'le tell you then, but can you hear well
When you do not ſleep? ſhall I ſpeak loud?

sp.speaker: Rob,
sp.l: Speak as you pleaſe, Sir, I ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And will you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: As long as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Have at him then.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Firſt then, I muſt tell you I am noble, and
Not of a common Birth; my father was a Gentleman,
But I am a better Gentleman then he: my
Way is courteous to all the world; I have every
Bodies good word; there's not a Footman in Toledo,
But had rather keep me Company then his Maſter:
Every one laughs to ſee me; what, you are aſleep already.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: No, no, no, Sir, I am attentive.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I excel all mankind in riding the great Horſe,
For at a Leap I throw my ſelf into the Saddle,
And with that ſwiftneſs, that 'tis unperceivable;
Then when I diſmount I caſt my ſelf off much
Better: which, you know, are remarkable proofs of
Agility: and for Valour, I am ſo full of it
I am ready to burſt; I ſing too like a Swan,
And dance like a Lunatick.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Thoſe are Qualities ſo becoming, I ever
Took delight in 'em; pray Sir, diſplay your Gifts
A little to my vein.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, no: I have left 'em off ever ſince I
Grew fat; but here's my man Pedro ſhall
Shew you ſomething of my teaching, to your
Admiration; nay, I am not a man of talk;
I have been as famous too at the Bull-ſport,
I have overthrown ſix in a day: my armes
Were once as good as any mans; and I could
Have hoiſted the Horns of a Bull, with as much
Eaſe as I have kill'd a wild Bore; Sirrah, you
Know this to be true.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now muſt I lie for him to ſave a beating.
I know you, Sir, to be ſo valiant, you would
Not flie, though purſu'd by an Army: and ſo
Stately, you would not riſe from your bed to ſalute a King.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Come, Sirrah, ſing me the Song I laſt made;
Nay, ſince you will be entertain'd, I'le ſhew you
Qualities which Sivel never could: come, come,
Begin; You know where, I ſet it in Sole fa.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sings ridiculouſly.

lg.head: THE SONG.
lg.l: Young I was, and yet not old:
Neither am I grown ſo cold;
But I can play, and I can twine
About a Virgin like a Vine.
In her Lap too I can lie
And return to life, if ſhe
Claps my cheeks, or kiſſes me:
So that by this you ſee't appears
Our Loves will ſtill out-laſt our Years.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis nothing to what I'le ſhew you:
I'le ſhew you Agility.
Now ſhrink your ſelf into a dwarf, now move
In that Figure: make me half a dozen of
Thoſe faces that I laſt painted,
Very well: now dance me an Antick.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This has ſome pleaſure in't.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hang him, the Rogue is lazy: I have a dog at
Home exceeds him in all but ſinging▪ I have
A great Judgment in painting too: could I but
Animate the Bodies that I form, my skill would
Outdo nature, I can with a touch of my Pencil
Shape a moſt •••• full face, paint Thunder and Lightning,
So as to make the beholder tremble; Day-break,
The riſing Sun, the Meridian, Raize and Duskey
Evening, Clouds and Meteors, Man, Beaſts, Plants,
Herbs, Flowers and Fruit, Fire and Water, Heaven
And Earth, Peace and War—How now, what do you
Sleep again: what a damn'd fop have I for a father in law.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Silence aſſiſt me, what a Monument of vanity is this?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Take courage, Sir, your eares are like to have a ſurfet.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now for good Husbandry, therein I yield to no man.
I have a juſt underſtanding in all things:
I laugh at them that laugh at me; as for my
Perſon 'tis not to be diſlik'd: what ſay you old man?
Is it not a goodly building? is not my foot
Well turn'd, and my legs well ſet on? Have
I not a Majeſtick deport, and Warlike look
As much, or more then yours.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Patience defend me, here are words enough to
Make a mans Memory ake: I thought, Sir,
You had ſome ſecrets to tell me; all theſe are
Nothing but windy praiſes caſt upon your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why you Cods-head, were they not ſecrets till
I told 'em you: Of your impertinence? this
Fooliſh fellow interrupts me ſo, I have
Forgot where I left off—did not I tell you,
You would be talking to me, before I had done—
My eſtate is ſix thouſand fourty two Duckets a year.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You told me that yeſterday—pray be ſhort, I
Love not meat twice dreſt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well, well, 'tis no matter, for that your Age weakens
Your Memory: but as I was a ſaying, having
This eſtate, I am reſolv'd to marry, and leave a
Race of Bertran's to the world, all ſuch as
Shall propagate my Name and Family; You have
A daughter whom I intended for my Spouſe; 'tis
True, ſhe is handſom, and 'tis time you ſhould diſpoſe
Of her, for you are old: and death may ſnatch you hence.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Are you in your Wits, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As much as ever he was.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Interruption, be attentive in the
Divel's name, and hear me out: I have
Heard you long enough already; but your old
VVhimſeycal pate is ſo full of vapours; you
Know not what you ſay or do.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I tell you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You ſhall tell me nothing, Sir: Death, can you
Tell me any thing I do not know already:
You will be ſtill reaſoning, and know nothing—
I tell you that this laſt night I heard a man in
Your Daughters Chamber, and I had taken him there,
But that they put ſtools in my way to prevent
It, did you know this?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As you are an old man, and ſuddenly expect your
Grave, is it fit to put me in ſuch fears at Midnight?
Hear me: I had rather marry a woman without a Noſe,
Then one that muſt be watch'd, to keep Her honeſt.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Will you be temperate, Sir, and hear me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Go, go, go: look for a fool elſewhere to
Humour you: I'le have none of her, ſhe is not
For my uſe; pay me but my Expences, I'le
Freely part with her; let all Promiſes be null,
Good friends, and ſo farewel.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have been told you wanted brains, and now you
Have prov'd it to me: do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes: you are an old ſottiſh Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, you Hog, you Swine, you boriſh Animal.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay, nay, nay: fume, fret, ſwear and dam: Give
Me a Releaſe, and take your daughter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: No, Sir; I'le make you know you have abus'd
My daughter, wrong'd my honour, injur'd my houſe,
And blemiſh'd my fame; and I'le have ſatisfaction
From the heart.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Death, what a dam'd cholerick old fellow is this?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Thou valiant, thou Hogſhead of oyl and filthineſs,
Come down if thou durſt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, my dear Dad, how I honour thy courage;
Should I be angry now, what would become
Of thee? but I have no power:
Come, give me thy hand; nay, nay, nay, Glove
And all; your Complement is but your own vexation.
Spare it; a ſoft word draws the ſoul out of me.
Well, I do conſent to eſpouſe your Daughter:
Goe get you in, Set all things in Readineſs,
My eſtate I'le Settle upon my children:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well we are friends again then:
You'll follow.—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I, I,—the Divell fetch him, Now what ſhall I doe,
I have no more mind to marry then to die.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This is the rare piece of obedience, Sir, you
Boaſted of: and ſwore you would defie the devil
To diſhoneſt her; I am ſorry your Judgment led
You into ſuch errors, for ſhe is a woman, and
Thoſe are a kind of locks, that every man▪
Has a Key too.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A Pox upon him, what would'ſt thou have me do?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Well Sir, what do you reſolve to marry or return?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, no, I am in again: the Match
Is made to my ſorrow: I have done what I
Could to break it, but that peeviſh old fellow,
Her father, would not conſent to it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Then, Sir you are miſerable.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why how ſhould I help it, I cannot get back
My Contract, that frothy old fool is every
Foot drawing his ſword: what if I had kill'd him?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Then he had been a dead man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I had certainly done it, but that there's an
Antipathy between me and the blood of a VVoodcock:
Beſides, my eſtate would have been confiſcate.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I have known you threaten death, Sir, for a leſs
Matter: breaking but your windows.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: To prevent danger, Sir, lay your affront upon
My ſword.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: VVhy, canſt thou fight?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Fight, look you, Sir, ha: Slap,

div.stage: [San. draws and offers to run at him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Sſiſh, thou art a divel at it: this Rogue has
Courage I find: but for all this, would I were
VVell back again in Toledo: theſe ſpirits
In Sivel are damnable furious: if I fight them,
I muſt either leave the VVorld or my Countrey;
And I find my ſelf very well in both.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Look you, Sir, you have no block to remove now
But him; for as I told you, your Rival, Caſſidore,
In my hearing confeſs'd, your Siſter had engag'd
To marry him, if he could gain but your conſent;
And that thing there is eaſily ſcar'd out of her;
Such a valiant nothing, that he is ready to run
Away from himſelf; like the Satyr that
Fled from the noiſe of a Horn which he himſelf made.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Enough, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How now, who is that?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I know not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I do not like his looks, ask him what he would have:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Sir, my Maſter deſires to know—

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Your Maſter's a Curr, and his men are whelps.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, what ſays he?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Sayes he; I know what he ſays, but you may reade
His meaning here, Sir—he has printed it with his Toes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A Pox of his ſhort hand.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What, beat my ſervants; I thank him for that
I faith; would he had done ſo much to me.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Be gone, you ſlaves, and leave us to our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Stir not, he that is upright need not covet privacie.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: What walking Dunghil is this, made of the
Duſt ſwept from the houſe of Ignorance.
You, with your Sarazens face; what, are you the toy that
Comes a wooing here; why thou Hee-goat, where
Haſt thou been hid i'th' world; thou haſt not been
The talk of Children.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Pedro, Sancho.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: I, I, Sir, we are here.

sp.speaker: Alva▪
sp.l: Do you hear, Mountain of Mummy,
You want a wife, do you; I'le wive you,
You ſhall ſee; come, Sir, ſince you wear a ſword,
You ſhall uſe one. Draw, nay, nay. Do it
Or I will ſhake thee into dripping: you muſt
Have a wife; why you ſhall have a wife: Come
Win her, and wear her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why Gentleman, Sir, let me be hang'd if I'le have
Any: ſhe is put upon me by her father, whether
I will or no.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Will you reſign her then?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: With all my heart, upon condition—

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You pay my expences hither; nay, 'tis not much,
But I would not be laught at in my own Countrey,
For loſing my labour, and my money too.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Provided, you never more renew your claim,
I'le do it willingly.

sp.speaker: Ber:
sp.l: Nay, nay, I'le be gone this Afternoon: go, Pedro,
Go you to the Inne, and get all things in readineſs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Well, we are agreed then.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: But Sir, what will her father ſay to this bargain?
You promiſ'd him to marry her preſently.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Let him ſay what he will, what a pax care I what
He ſays; Am I bound to humour him; I'le marry her
To whom I pleaſe, ſhe is mine as long as he
Keeps my Contract.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Well Sir, do your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Come, let us in, and ſee what your Expences come to.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: So now the Bargain's made, I'le homeward Hop,
And deal no more in love, but ſhut up ſhop.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: BEr.
sp.l: Come, come, Sirrah, knock at the door.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Its open, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: That's all one, knock when I bid you.

sp.speaker: San:
sp.l: Why, Sir, you may go in without knocking,
The Door invites you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sirrah, ſirrah, learn more manners; do
As I bid you: Knock, or I'le knock a peal
Upon your pate; I will not come under her
Roof, her dealings have been baſe; knock louder,
Louder yet, I'le ſtarve and rot firſt:
The open Air is every mans.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Who is it knocks: O Signior, is it you?
Will you be pleaſed to walk in, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, I am none of your walk-in, Sirs: I am in
Too far already, I would I had my Contract:
This Rogue (I have married her to) will not
Pay me my Expences, till he has my Contract;
Up: go, go, bid your wiſe Maſter come out to me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But me no Butts, hold your prating
Houſwife, do you ſtand there to ask men
Queſtions? tell your Maſter I am here.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Well Sir: I ſhall acquaint him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I go in? I'le firſt go into a Peſt-houſe▪ by this
Light, I had rather have twenty wives then have
Such a father in Law.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Marry Sir: would we were well at home again▪
The Town they call Sivil, but the uſage is not ſo:
I have ſcarce had a belly full ſince I came;
Their Kid and Garlick, Zant Oyle and
Sallad: with half a Hen amongſt ſix of us.
I have an Engliſh ſtomack, and could digeſt
A Chine of Beef; I love my belly beſt of any
Thing; 'tis neerer to me then my Kindred.—
Hang this wooing, and all that profeſs it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: In quotha? Catch me in their houſe again

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, Signiour Bartran, I hope I have given you no
Cauſe to leave my houſe in Anger.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O good Signiour Antiquity! I know you well enough
For a fair tongu'd man, but I care not for
Your Apologie, as little for your love, I can
Live without both: Eat my own, and ſleep
Without dependencies.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now you talk gently, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No matter what I talk, I am not ſo gentle
Neither, nor will not be; this ſha'nt cog me
Into a Marriage: But if I marry her, may
The devil carry me away upon my
Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Will you hear reaſon?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, I'le hear no reaſon: reaſon! I am not
To be popp'd off with reaſon: your Daughter I
Have diſpoſ'd of, Give me my Contract, and
There's an end.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, Signiour, in all things there muſt be method▪
You choak the child of honour, the diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well, well, I know what I do without your
Direction: I am not to be tutor'd by ſuch an
Old fool as you: my cauſe is no mans but
My own; Give me my Contract, or by
Heaven, I'le fire your houſe, and that's my
Way of honour.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Perfectly Lunatick.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As for your daughter, I have no more to ſay to her,
I have recall'd the Vows I made to her; and
I am no longer oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Pray lets argue ſomething temperately like men.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Like men?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You are too ſudden.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Like men, Sir!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I Sir, like men, 'tis fair language.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why, doſt hear old fellow, what ſtrange beaſt
Would your grave reverence make me appear?
Like men! I tell thee, fellow, I am as much a man,
And as good a man.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: All this is granted, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And as wiſe a man.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: True, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As any man. And a man dares make thee no
Man, or at leaſt a baſe man and an old man.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What, do you laugh, you Vulture?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, thou Antique fool, thou Morrice-dancer:
Since thou haſt again provok'd me, thou
Shalt have no contract; come, ſay thy
Prayers, thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I ſcorn thee, and ſcorn to ſay my prayers
More then thou doſt.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir, bear a little with his follies
'Tis rather a diſeaſe then temper in him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Take heed, urge me no more; if I draw once
I ſhall kill thee: and (like a rotten Pumpeon)
Leave thy old Carcaſs ſtinking to Poſterity.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: VVhy thou ridiculous Varlet, how durſt thou
Talk of killing, or drawing any thing but
Thy breath, which ſtinks more then a putrified
Marrow-bone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sancho, come hither: he is too old to fight with;
Prithee, take me in thy Armes, and throw me
At that Puppy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Get thee out of my houſe thou over-grown
Aſs, Dunghil, Quagmire, (or what is worſe)
All filths moulded up in one deteſted Lump;
If I have ſtood a patient Anvil to all thy
Lunatick fits, 'twas in compaſſion to thy Age
And weakneſs. But now I can no longer bear
It. Begone (I ſay) or I'le ſend an Officer to
VVhip thee out of Town.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: VVhip me ont of Town! O fire and brimſtone:
Whip me out of Town? I'le ſhew him a trick for that.
Go, Sirrah, run to the Inne, and get my Mule
Sadled preſently.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir, and glad of the Office;
Farewel Sivil; I'le leave your Kid and Garlick
To the devil.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Whip me out of Town! O that he were but
Young enough for my revenge, that I might
Kill him, and be juſtified in honour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, my Lady hears you are going away, and
She is come to take her leave.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I have no more to ſay to her, ſhe is
Too frail a wife for me; ſhe is awake at midnight,
When other women ſleep.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Go, go, you are a petulant froward Aſs, a baby of 70.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: An old doting iniquity of Age:
You make a bedfellow, a broom-ſtick would
Make a better.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How! the ſcoff of Petticoats!

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: A child at mans eſtate: Puff-paſte, Fleſh-flie.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Dare you provoke me thus?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A wife! the fool muſt have a rattle.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: You nauſeous wretch.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You Sea-Calf.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: You Land-whale.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You heap of Atoms kneaded into fleſh.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Patience, here's a bed of Snakes within me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Durſt thou venture on a Lady in the Summer
And hunting ſeaſon of her youth? Threeſcore
And ſix, to have and to hold a Maiden-head
Of eighteen: look, look, how he grumbles
Behind his board.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: The contempt of women, and the ſhame of men.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Go, go, march (Memento mori)
She'll deal no more in old fleſh.
Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

div.stage: [both laugh; he runs at Jul▪ with his ſword.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: By Heaven, Huſwife, I'le ſpoil your laughing.

div.stage: Enter Sophia and Attendance, and Addibar meeting her.

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: Madam, my Maſter is ready to attend.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Heaven guide my tongue to expreſs my ſorrows
In that penſive nature, that it may fill his
Soul with a juſt loathing of Alvaro and his
Siſter; ſuch heavy news as mine muſt gently
Sink into him by degrees.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Moſt dear Madam, thus low I beg the
Honour of your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: The thoughts of what I have to ſay, gives an
Increaſe to all the terrors of my heart.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Heavens! what unuſual grief is this:
I was not us'd to kneel thus long in vain:

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I fear to give thee thy deſires, leſt I ſhould
Caſt away my bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: How have I deſerv'd this ſeparation from your love?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: [Riſe, and I'le unfold the ſecret to thee.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pray Madam, ſpeak, for this attentive ear,
Cannot hear worſe, then 'tis prepar'd to hear.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I am rob'd of all that vital heat that
Fed my life with joy.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You come with Cripples pace to that which
You ſhould flie to.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Take it at once then, thy Siſter, thy poor
Siſter Semena, is raviſh'd from me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Raviſhed! may the unwearied Sun
For ever ſhroud, that horrid day within
Some fatal cloud.
And may that night eternally be blind,
Leſt in it ſelf, nor to the day rejoyn'd.
Tell me the man that did that horrid deed.
And were he fenc'd with fire, he ſhould
Not 'ſcape vengeance.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: O may each Sun-ſhine, a new bleſſing on
Thee; I'le twine thee to me in theſe armes,
As Ivy locks the Elm in her Embraces;
Now take all the bleſſing
I can give thee.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I am impatient till I hear his name,
My ſword had never nobler thirſt of blood.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Alvaro was the man.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Alvaro! O lend me temper, Heaven.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I'le tell thee all, ſince thy reſentments are
So great; I was a long time ſolicited
By friends to give her him to wife, and
With purpoſe to put a Period to all the
Variances that had long reigned in
Both our Families. He counted her (as
I thought,) with noble paſſion: but when
The day was ſet, and all things ready to
Conſummate the Marriage, he moſt
Ignobly left her, and took his flight for
Spain; and hath in Sivil there, as I am
Inform'd, reſided ever ſince. Your Siſter
Full of grief, remained ſome days
Behind him, but ſoon after was not to
Be heard of.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You have Comet-ſtruck my amaz'd ſoul.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Reade; but this Letter 'twill confirm all truth.

body.p:
This Paper will advertiſe you of an
Unhappineſs inſupportable, the moſt diſloyal
Of all Mankind, (that Infidel) Alvaro, is
Author of more miſery to me then I can
Utter. He only hath drawn me from the
Bleſſing of your Preſence, which I deſpair ever
To enjoy again, and therefore muſt of
Force remain.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: VVhat killing Accents hath my ears
Received, ſinking the ſoul with the report.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: A truth ſo diſmal is almoſt incredible.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Alvaro raviſh'd her.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Though this was a Misfortune Charity
Could not pardon; yet I, ſupported with a
Matchleſs patience, and publickly diffus'd
The Rumour of her death, the better to
Diſguiſe our infamy.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: None can tell how much my heart ſhares
In your ſorrows, Madam, by the ſad aſhes
Of my Fathers grave; this is a Crime deſerves
The vengeance of the Heavens.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Your threatnings are but as feathers flying
In the Air, 'tis now a time to puniſh,
Not complain; in ſuch dire Acts as theſe
We beſt expreſs our troubles by our revenge:
Complaints are Womens Oratory: but
Valour is the Rhetorick of man: ſince
The injury is deadly, the reparation ought
To be the ſame: Now thou knoweſt the Offend • r
Flie to thy revenge; had Nature enabled
Me for ſuch an Action, thou hadſt not
Known the crime: I conjure thee therefore
On my bleſſing, ſee me no more till thou
Haſt drown'd this ſhame in blood.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Alas, what counſel ſhall I take, whoſe
Life I ſeek, to him for mine I owe: he ſav'd
The brother, but the ſiſter hath deſtroy'd.
Can Heaven ſuffer me to ſpill his blood,
Who was the deare preſerver once of mine:
Blood too that I have ſome ſhare in, for
My Jacinta runs in half his veines.
Yonder ſhe comes, honour would have me
Fly her; but there's another power more
Uncontroulable, ſubdues that thought and
Binds me to her worſhip; O why did not the malice
Of my fate, Conferr this guilt
On one that I could hate?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Doſt thou obſerve (Livia) how unwilling
He is to ſee mee? Let us paſs by him
Without a word.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Faireſt of Creatures, Creations purity,
Thou Charm of all my Senſes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Your Adorations, Sir, are miſapplied.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: 'Tis not from cuſtom, Madam, but from
Sympathy my heart thus bowes to you;
I know my devotions to be more juſt
Then to be led by errour.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Look you, Sir, what think you now?
Am I ſo like Alleria, you cannot
Know the one from t'other?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Alleria, Madam: I had err'd indeed, had
I ſuſpected that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, never counterfeit, I am ſure you
Took me for her.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Take heed, Signior, your diſſimulation doth
Not prejudice you, my Lady is going to
Her, and ſhee'll tell her all.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now I am inſtructed whence this change comes;
Perhaps, Madam, you conjecture my intimacy
With her father, was in order to prefer ſome
Amorous deſign to her; but I ſwear to you,
Your Image only fills my heart, whatever
In her was lovely I have often view'd,
Without the leaſt ſurprize.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: How far will his hypocriſie extend?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Could you think, Madam, after I beheld you.
I could have a thought of zeal to any other.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O monſtrous, thou art as falſe as ſin unto the ſoul.
Thy face as full of Lies as Gipſies.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You confound me with your imputations: I am as
Innocent in this, as the unſtain'd ſoul of truth.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Is it to be innocent to counterfeit a paſſion to me,
And then abandon me to the reproaches of all tongues;
Nay more, to fawn, cringe and doat upon another,
On purpoſe to afflict and perſecute my timorous ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Who, Madam, has miſguided your belief ſo much?
May all the curſes rage and malice wiſh, fall on me,
If ever I had thoughts of ſwerving from my firſt Vow.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Good Heavens! can ſuch an Imprecation paſs without
A Judgment from the Over-hearer? what Plagues can
Be too great for him that is to marry one he
Does not love, and yet forſwears it ſo.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I marry her, then may Miſery in all its
Loath'd formes cohabit with me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O infidel! why every one is advertis'd of it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Tell me but the Author of this abuſe,
And I will write it on his heart in ſtabs. He lies.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You dare not do it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: By all that's ſacred, and can make an Oath, I dare.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: It was Alleria; now tell me if you have a ſoul,
VVhether you dare preſerve it?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O was it ſhe: alas, Madam, do you vindicate
The truth of her reports, ſhe did it with deſign
On purpoſe to abuſe you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Can guilt maintain ſuch confidence?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Do but hear me, Madam: may I be
Thunder-ſtruck: and in this place ſtand fixt, an
Eternal Prodigie of falſeneſs, if ever I had
For Alleria more then a fair Civility.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I will yet try him further, will you prove
The truth of this?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You ſhall have a thouſand proofs to undeceive you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I'le have but one; Give me your hand and faith.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I'le give it you with joy; Honour defend me, what
sp.stage: [Offers readily to pull off his Glove, then checks himſelf.
sp.l: Was I about to do, give her the Hand that muſt
Her Brother ſlay.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I know my demands would ſtartle you: your
Guilt, by your Reluctance, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: So great an honour, Madam, muſt needs ſurprize
A heart that did ſo little expect it; your cruelty
Before fill'd me with deſpair: and this exceſſive
Favour aſtoniſh'd my unwary hopes; beſides, I
Fear'd if I obey'd you, 'twould be a blemiſh to your
Honour: and that your Brother might be incens'd againſt
Me, if I accepted of your heart, without his Gift;
But though theſe thoughts were worthy of debate,
My reſolution has o'recom 'em all: Now nothing ſhall
Diſappoint me of the glory of your favour.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No Sir, now you accept too late, the deſires I had
Are vaniſh'd, never to be recall'd.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I beſeech you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jac▪
sp.l: My doubts are now confirm'd; when I requir'd
Your faith, the thoughts you had for her withheld
You from the Gift; and your diſordered looks
Aſſur'd me, ſhe was Poſſeſſor of the demands
I made.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Madam, upon my Knees I tender it to you now.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: It is not in your power to diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Why have you taught your ears a ſcornful deafneſs?
Is it to make my miſery longer liv'd?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: In vain are all your importunities,
When ſenſe of wrongs our reſolutions blind,
No ſupplication ſhould reverſe the mind.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now is my ſoul expos'd to newer toiles, muſt
I ſuffer with ſubmiſſive patience, the pains due
To a crime I never did, and when Juſtice calls me
To revenge, muſt I at the ſame time be unfortunate
In my love; but here's my enemy, whom yet
I have not power to hate.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Sure he has trod on burning coals, he has made
Such haſte from me.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: No matter, Sir, I hear her wound is dreſt,
She is well again, it was more fright then harm.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Speak heart, ſhall I embrace him, or
Shall I pierce his heart.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O there's my Rival, Lyſander, leave us to our ſelves▪
Give me, ye gods, a wrath natur'd like lightning;
A new invented ſpleen to talk unto this Monſter.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Though he has deſerv'd my utmoſt hatred, I love
Him not ſo ill, to leave him in a danger; I fear
They'l fight, and therefore will not be far diſtant.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: That Juſtice that holds up my ſword faces it
And turns his Advocate, what unjuſt grief is this
Afflicts my worthy friend?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Canſt thou be my Tormentor; and ask me ſuch
A Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What's this, who is't has diſcompoſ'd thee ſo?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: One whoſe injuries I muſt puniſh with his death.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Prithee make me worthy of the glory to aſſiſt
Thee in it.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I cannot perfect my revenge without you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Alvarez, of all my blood you may diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: It is an offer that I cannot refuſe.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What man hath Fate mark'd out to be ſo wicked,
To be thy Offender?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thou art audacious to an extream, doſt thou
Not know it is thy ſelf?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Make it appear that I have wrong'd thee
(So much as in a thought) at this inſtant,
VVill I bring the Victime to the Altar.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Dam your hypocriſie, draw.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Ah friend, what do I owe thee for this indignation?
VVere the obligations thou haſt ſo often caſt
Upon me, capable of Addition, they were increas'd
In this Invective; thou haſt opened
That precipice to thy own ruine, which all the
VVorld beſides could not have done, my heart
Excited with the ſenſe of its own wrongs, juſtly
Deſign'd thy death; but when my Arm was
Bent upon the Act, thy ſight (alone) made
It a ſin to wiſh it.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thou ſtrangleſt whilſt thou flattreſt.
I'le hear no more, defend thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Thy reſolution is to me moſt pleaſing, I have
Greater cauſe to fight thee, then thou canſt
Imagine: yet tell me what animates thy fury,
That I may ſhew thee thy deceit, and juſtifie
My ſelf in killing thee.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O that Thunder and Lightning were in my power,
That I might ſtrike thee dead.
Does not thy treacherous ſoul uſurp the
Glory of my cares: haſt thou not ſeduc'd
My Myſtriſs from me, and tomorrow art
To marry her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: If I am criminal, that's not
My offence; Alleria was ever far from
The reach of my hopes; no, no, thou canſt
Only reproach me, that without acquainting thee,
I have made love unto thy Siſter.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: My Siſter, may I believe this?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Is there faith in vertue?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: How has my miſtruſt miſguided me:
Theſe are the Arms I draw againſt thee now,
My Siſter never could have aſpired to ſuch a
Fortune, a man ſo truly noble.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Hold Sir, though you are ſatisfied, I am not,
There let that Paper tell thee, the baſeſt Act
sp.stage: [Throws him his Siſters Letter to his Mother.
sp.l: That ever yet defil'd Humanity.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Are they not both in errour?

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: This is a pretty odd kind of interview,
Knew 'em greet one another after this manner
Before.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: By my life, friend, I comprehend nothing.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Thou art but the picture of a friend: have
I wrapt and woven thee into all Truſts and Counſels,
To be pernicious to my honour.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Canſt thou ſuſpect me guilty of ſo black a deed,
By all that's good, thy Siſter
Is a chaſte (for ought I know) as the unſulli'd
Lilly: do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: No: deaf as a remorſeleſs ſea▪ my wrongs have made me

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: VVas thy life ſav'd to this end?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I owe thee nothing, ſince thou didſt it to
Upbraid me with it.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Him that love wounds, no other wounds can fear.

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: More miſchief; help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: O that ſome ſtriking Air had blaſted me,
Before I ſaw this moment: Hold, hold, Sir, hold;
For Heavens ſake, hold.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Away, Boy.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: I muſt not, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sirrah, forbear.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: May that ſword that ſtrikes at each of you.
Fall from the Hilt, and want a power to hurt you.

div.stage: Enter Addibar again, bringing Robatzy, Alleria, Sophia, Jaccinta, Julia, Livia and Caſſidore, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: Here, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Hold, good Gentlemen, hold!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Kill him.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Save him.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: No, no, my ſon, bravely purſue thy revenge▪
Baſe man thou art to practiſe thy deceit
Upon an innocent Child, the Jewel of my heart,
The Hope and Comfort of my years.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come, come, Madam: this is no time for Exclamation.
The contention is too high to be appeas'd with words.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: They ſhall not fight.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But they ſhall, Sir, come draw, old as I am
I'le find employment for your ſword.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: O ſtay your bloody wills: behold not what I ſeem,
But what I am: the unhappy cauſe of this
Unluckie diſcord.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What phrenzy is this?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Semena, Madam: your moſt unfortunate Daughter

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Semena?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: O let me embrace thee, thou art ſhe indeed:
I know thee, by the Muſick of thy tongue:
My Joys have now ore'come my fears.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I am ſtruck dumb with the ſurprize, Semena?

sp.speaker: Lyſ▪
sp.l: The very ſame Semena that heard you
Vow, and did believe you: that fool that
Did not think you could have flattered.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Madam, I confeſs, that in the face of Heaven we
Exchang'd hearts, gave faith for faith; but he is near
A god that is lord over his eye, when my wandring looks
Glanc'd upon other Beauties; yours, Madam, like a
Cloud chaſ'd by the wind, fled from my Memory.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: O ſpeak, my child, my ears are greedy
To receive thy ſtories:

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: VVhen the fair Gem of my love was by
Your perſwaſion, Madam, given to that diſloyal
Man, ſcarce had one Moon run out her time,
But he, perfidious as he was, left me the ſcorn of women:
Notwithſtanding this,
My afflicted heart yearnd after him, and my
Hopes perſwaded me, that thus diſguis'd, I
Poſſibly might find him in ſome part of
Spain, whither reporr inform'd me he was
Fled: At length I had Advice that he was
Here in Sivil, and turn'd a Proſelite to anothers
Love; upon which (with ſtrict Enquiry having found
Him,) I gain'd an intereſt to get into his ſervice,
And gladly executed all Commands of his, even
Such as were deſtructive to my own peace and quiet.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: O let me drop upon thy cheeks theſe tears
Of joy.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Dear Siſter, thou art more welcom to theſe eyes,
Then was the firſt light to the diſordered Chaos.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Here, as your Deſpiſer, Madam, ſtrike
My heart aſunder, but ſave the new born
Love within it: be juſt unto your ſelf, and kill me.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Kill you, not for the world.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: The world will Saint you for doing her ſuch
Service, and all chaſte Maids that meet
VVith miſeries modell'd out by yours, would build
You Altars, and yearly on the day you did
This deed▪ would make them flame
With thankful Sacrifices: Kill me, for I am ſo
Inconſtant, 'tis dangerous to the world they
Should have my example.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Contrition, Sir, has carried you into a noble Figure.
All the reſentments of my wrongs, your Penitence
Has overcome.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I bluſh I have but one ſoul to offer you.
This Act of Pardon, Madam, is a bounty as matchleſs
As your vertue: Now if your honoured Parent would think
Me worthy of her Indempnity, nothing ſhall prevent
Our union.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: I do not want the pity you deny'd to her;
But I am ready to forget what's paſt, and meet your wiſhes
With all willingneſs.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Hereafter we will be like ſtreams which flow
In curle together, and no difference know.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now friend (for ſo I muſt again call thee)
My Fate hangs on thy lips, in thy happineſs,
Thy Siſter depends only on thy diſpoſure.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nothing can be too worthy of thee.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now are my Joys compleat.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: All my ſuſpitions are now extinguiſh'd, and
Give me leave to tell you, (yet not without a
Bluſh) that in this I as well obey my own deſires
As my brothers, though Caſſidore will complain on't.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: You are miſtaken, Madam: to ſhew, that I
Repine not at your fortune, I am converted to
This Lady; there's but one billow more to fill
This Tyde: Madam, your fathers breath may
Do it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, in my daughters Choice my ſatisfaction bounds.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: You have ſo many ways oblig'd me,
I can deny you nothing, where I owe my life,
I well may owe my love.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Here Sir, take her, and with her take my bleſſing

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Our two ſouls, like well-tun'd inſtruments
Shall now make up one Simphony:
So thoſe Notes that at the firſt ſeem diſcords,
Conclude in a moſt pleaſing Harmony.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Madam, I hope to have your friendſhip,
Though I go without your love.

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: You ſhall now have both, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: And mine too; we now are friends, too
Strong for Fate to break.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come then, let Muſick be prepar'd,
And all the ſhews of joy that Mirth
Can make: ſince our Diſaſters are ſo well
Compos'd, we'll turn this day into a Jubilee.
They that thus wait the leiſure of their Fate,
Advantage find to be unfortunate.
